letter to founders, Apple’s folding device and the DOJ’s new stance on hackers"},"content":{"rendered":""speakable-summary\">Hi all!<\/p>\nWelcome back to Week in Review, our"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/newsletters\">newsletter<\/a> where we wrap up many of the top stories to hit TechCrunch over the last seven days.<\/p>\nThebig thing<\/strong> this week, based on what people were reading most, were the details of a memo sent from Y Combinator to its portfolio founders.<\/p>\nAs the markets continue to slide,YC is telling its portfolio founders that it’s time to batten down the hatches \u2014 cut costs, extend runway and get to a “default alive” state. “For those of you who have started your company within the last 5 years,” YC writes, “question what you believe to be the normal fundraising environment.”<\/p>\nManish has the"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/19\/yc-advises-founders-to-plan-for-the-worst\/\">full 10-point email right here.<\/a><\/p>\nother things<\/h2>\nBesides more bad news about the markets, what else was going on?<\/em><\/p>\n"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/17\/apple-reportedly-testing-e-ink-outer-display-for-upcoming-foldable\/\">Apple testing a foldable?:<\/strong><\/a> Is Apple tinkering with the idea of folding phones and\/or tablets? Analyst Ming-Chi Kuo says Apple is testing E-Ink displays for the secondary display on an as-of-yet-unseen “future foldable”. As Brian points out, though, “there\u2019s a big gulf between testing and releasing” \u2014 in other words, don’t be too surprised if this one never sees the light of day.<\/p>"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/18\/nhtsa-probes-tesla-autopilot-crash-that-killed-three-people\/\">NHTSA probes Tesla crash:<\/strong><\/a> Earlier this month, a Tesla Model S “hit a curb and slammed into construction equipment”, killing three. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration is now looking into the accident to determine if Tesla’s Autopilot system could’ve been involved.<\/p>\n"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/19\/justice-department-good-fatih-hackers-cfaa\/\">DOJ says it will no longer prosecute good-faith hackers:<\/strong><\/a> After way, way, way too long, the U.S. Justice Department is re-evaluating how it looks at hacking cases, for the first time outright stating that “good-faith security research should not be charged” under the Computer Fraud and Abuse Act.<\/p>\n"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/20\/coca-cola-bottle-cap\/\">Haje on Coke’s new bottle cap:<\/strong><\/a> “When [Coke] sends out a hand-wringing press release about how awesome they are for launching a bottle cap where the cap stays attached to the bottle ‘for environmental reasons,'” writes Haje, “I\u2019m sorry, my blood just boils.”<\/p>\n"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/16\/three-paypal-ventures-alums-strike-out-with-their-own-158m-fund\/\">PayPal Ventures alums launch a new fund:<\/strong><\/a> Within a few months of parting ways with PayPal Ventures, these three alums had raised a huge new fund of their own. The focus? Fintech, and backing “startups that address ‘the biggest hurdles’ in today\u2019s financial infrastructure: access, utility, flexibility, and cost.”<\/p>\nadded things<\/h2>\nWe have a paywalled section of our site called"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/subscribe?tpcc=homepagetout\">TechCrunch+<\/a>. It costs a few bucks a month and it\u2019s full of very good stuff! From this week, for example:<\/em><\/p>\n"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/16\/start-up-solo-or-bring-on-a-co-founder-4-factors-to-consider\/\">Solo or co-founder?:<\/strong><\/a> You’re starting a company. Do you do it alone, or find a co-founder? It’s a question I’ve heard asked pretty much every time I’ve been on a panel with VCs or founders. In this post, co-founder of DocSend (acquired by Dropbox in 2021) Russ Heddleston shares his thoughts.<\/p>\n"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/16\/how-quickly-are-startup-layoffs-accelerating\/\">Are startup layoffs accelerating?:<\/strong><\/a> It feels like we’re hearing about new layoffs every other day. How quickly are startup layoffs accelerating? Alex Wilhelm dives into the data.<\/p>\n"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/20\/salty-subterranean-water-could-relieve-worlds-lithium-shortage\/\">Relieving the world\u2019s lithium shortage:<\/strong><\/a> Lithium-ion batteries, as the name suggests, require lithium. But “today\u2019s lithium mines can\u2019t hope to meet the skyrocketing demand,” writes Tim De Chant. So where will we get it moving forward? Tim takes a look at some potential solutions.<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"Hi all! to The TechCrunch Podcast!"},"content":{"rendered":""speakable-summary\">Welcome to the very first episode of The TechCrunch Podcast! Every week, the new TC podcast will dive into the biggest stories in tech, as told by the writers who penned them. We’ve been developing and iterating on the concept for many months now, so we’re thrilled to finally be able to deliver our first ever full episode, which you can get by subscribing"https:\/\/podcasts.apple.com\/us\/podcast\/the-techcrunch-podcast\/id1624500693\">here on Apple Podcasts<\/a> or"https:\/\/open.spotify.com\/show\/7gaqQOeUbC6hfMkVA5fih3?si=b30642b7f1e54ea5\">Spotify<\/a>.<\/p>\nOur first ever show is typical for TechCrunch, since it was recorded mostly on the road at one of our fantastic yearly events \u2013"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/events\/tc-sessions-mobility-2022\/\">TechCrunch Mobility 2022<\/a>! If there’s one thing TC is great at, it’s rolling with the punches and improvising on the fly, and we did that with on-location and remote recording, bringing you highlights from the biggest news of the week alongside in-depth interviews with TC’s own Kirsten Korosec and Taylor Hatmaker.<\/p>\nBe sure to subscribe, and leave us a 5-star review with your feedback. We’ll be delivering the TechCrunch Podcast weekly, with fresh interviews from the writers closest to the biggest stories of the week, as well as a roundup of what you need to know for what went down in the wide world of tech.<\/p>\n"https:\/\/player.simplecast.com\/3cffe965-f16a-4584-b69d-87e67f0d751f?dark=false\" width=\"100%\" height=\"200px\" frameborder=\"no\" scrolling=\"no\" seamless=\"\"><\/iframe><\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"Welcome to the very first episode of The TechCrunch Podcast! Every week, the new TC podcast will dive into the biggest stories in tech, as told by the writers who penned them. ref":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=577017946"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=577017946"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=577017946"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=577017946"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":576595654,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/the-techcrunch-podcast\/","name":"The TechCrunch Podcast","slug":"the-techcrunch-podcast","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/576595654"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=576595654"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=576595654"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=576595654"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=576595654"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":67677,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/ufo\/","name":"UFO","slug":"ufo","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/67677"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=67677"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=67677"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=67677"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=67677"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2322352,"date":"2022-05-21T11:20:29","date_gmt":"2022-05-21T18:20:29","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2322352"},"modified":"2022-05-20T14:16:44","modified_gmt":"2022-05-20T21:16:44","slug":"this-week-in-apps-snapchat-policy-checkup-more-twitter-deal-drama-tiktok-games","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/21\/this-week-in-apps-snapchat-policy-checkup-more-twitter-deal-drama-tiktok-games\/","title":{"rendered":"This Week in Apps: Snapchat policy checkup, more Twitter deal drama, TikTok games"},"content":{"rendered":""speakable-summary\">Welcome back to This Week in Apps,"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/this-week-in-apps\/\">the weekly TechCrunch series<\/a> that recaps the latest in mobile OS news, mobile applications and the overall app economy.<\/p>\nThe app industry continues to grow, with"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/12\/07\/app-stores-to-see-record-consumer-spend-of-133-billion-in-2021-143-6-billion-new-app-installs\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">a record<\/a> number of downloads and consumer spending across both the iOS and Google Play stores combined in 2021, according to the"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/12\/07\/app-stores-to-see-record-consumer-spend-of-133-billion-in-2021-143-6-billion-new-app-installs\/\">latest<\/a> year-end"https:\/\/www.appannie.com\/en\/insights\/market-data\/2021-end-year-mobile-apps-recap\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">reports<\/a>. App Annie says global spending across iOS and Google Play is up to $135 billion in 2021, and that figure will likely be higher when its annual report, including third-party app stores in China, is released next year. Consumers also downloaded 10 billion more apps in 2021 than in 2020, reaching nearly 140 billion in new installs, it found.<\/p>\nApps aren\u2019t just a way to pass idle hours \u2014 they\u2019re also a big business. In 2019, mobile-first companies had a"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/01\/15\/app-stores-saw-record-204-billion-app-downloads-in-2019-consumer-spend-of-120-billion\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">combined<\/a> $544 billion valuation, 6.5x higher than those without a mobile focus. In 2020, investors"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/01\/13\/app-stores-saw-record-218-billion-downloads-in-2020-consumer-spend-of-143-billion\/\">poured<\/a> $73 billion in capital into mobile companies \u2014 a figure that was up 27% year-over-year.<\/p>\nThis Week in Apps offers a way to keep up with this fast-moving industry in one place with the latest from the world of apps, including news, updates, startup fundings, mergers and acquisitions, and much more.<\/p>\nDo you want This Week in Apps in your inbox every Saturday? Sign up here:"http:\/\/techcrunch.com\/newsletters\">techcrunch.com\/newsletters<\/a><\/strong><\/em><\/p>\nTop Stories<\/h1>\nApps celebrate Global Accessibility Awareness Day<\/h3>\nThis past Thursday, May 19, 2022, marked the 11th Global Accessibility Awareness Day (GAAD), which is a day focused on raising awareness about digital access and inclusion for the more than 1 billion people who live with disabilities or impairments. A number of app makers and tech companies took part in GAAD this year to either highlight or announce new features designed to better meet the needs of those with vision impairment, hearing loss and other disabilities.<\/p>\nInstagram’s"https:\/\/about.instagram.com\/micro_site\/url\/?click_from_context_menu=true&country=US&destination=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.instagram.com%2Fcreators%2F&event_type=click&last_nav_impression_id=1CdGKXYlYDe4E0lHE&max_percent_page_viewed=64&max_viewport_height_px=650&max_viewport_width_px=1440&orig_request_uri=https%3A%2F%2Fabout.instagram.com%2Fblog%2Ftips-and-tricks%2Fadvancing-accessibility-on-instagram%2F&region=noam&scrolled=true&session_id=0CY7cymmK4zmFenWR&site=instagram_about\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">@creators account<\/a> shared information with its community about how and why to use accessibility features, like alt-text and auto-generated captions to create a better experience for your audience. The company"https:\/\/about.instagram.com\/blog\/tips-and-tricks\/advancing-accessibility-on-instagram\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">also noted other developments<\/a> it had rolled out, like dark mode, screen reader improvements, improved automatic and custom alternative text options for people with vision impairments, caption stickers for Reels and Stories, and more. The company also said it has started rolling out closed caption features to improve the Instagram experience for the deaf and hard of hearing communities. These changes help to improve the experience for everyone, however, as Instagram said one-third of video plays on Instagram are with the sound off. In March, Instagram made"u_0_c_aa\" class=\"_8ow9 _9gii\" href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/instagram\/status\/1498710216585613314\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">"_8-vl _8-vp\">"_95iu _8iqw\">auto-generated captions the default<\/span><\/span><\/a> for creators, which are supported globally across iOS and Android.<\/p>"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\nGoogle shared its approach to both hiring people with disabilities and building products to meet their needs. For example, it highlighted projects like"https:\/\/blog.google\/outreach-initiatives\/accessibility\/project-relate\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-analytics-onclick=\"{"event":"page interaction","category":"in-article links","action":"link click","label":"https:\/\/blog.google\/outreach-initiatives\/accessibility\/project-relate\/"}\">Project Relate<\/a>, a communication tool for people with speech impairments; the update to"https:\/\/blog.google\/products\/android\/all-new-talkback\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-analytics-onclick=\"{"event":"page interaction","category":"in-article links","action":"link click","label":"https:\/\/blog.google\/products\/android\/all-new-talkback\/"}\">\u00a0TalkBack<\/a>, Android\u2019s built-in screen reader; and the"https:\/\/blog.google\/products\/chromebooks\/accessibility-features\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-analytics-onclick=\"{"event":"page interaction","category":"in-article links","action":"link click","label":"https:\/\/blog.google\/products\/chromebooks\/accessibility-features\/"}\">improved Select-to-Speak<\/a> Chromebook tool; a multi-pin feature for Google Meet, which allows users to pin multiple tiles, like a presenter’s screen and interpreter’s screen. The company also noted all its English-language YouTube Originals content from the past year \u2014 and moving forward \u2014 will now have English audio descriptions available globally.<\/p>\nApple, meanwhile, participated in GAAD with a number of"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/17\/apple-adds-live-captions-to-iphone-and-mac-plus-more-accessibility-upgrades-to-come\/\">announcements<\/a> about"https:\/\/www.apple.com\/newsroom\/2022\/05\/apple-previews-innovative-accessibility-features\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">new accessibility features<\/a> for iPhone, Apple Watch and Mac.<\/p>\nThese included a universal Live Captions feature, improved visual and auditory detection modes and iOS access to WatchOS apps. Live Captions will be able to transcribe any audio content, like FaceTime calls, video conferencing apps and streaming video, as well as in-person conversations, all in English to start.<\/p>\n"attachment_2322399\" style=\"width: 1970px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\">"caption-attachment-2322399\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"wp-image-2322399 size-full\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/05\/Apple-Accessibility-OS-features-2022-hero_big.jpg.large_2x.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1960\" height=\"1102\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/05\/Apple-Accessibility-OS-features-2022-hero_big.jpg.large_2x.jpg 1960w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/05\/Apple-Accessibility-OS-features-2022-hero_big.jpg.large_2x.jpg?resize=150,84 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/05\/Apple-Accessibility-OS-features-2022-hero_big.jpg.large_2x.jpg?resize=300,169 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/05\/Apple-Accessibility-OS-features-2022-hero_big.jpg.large_2x.jpg?resize=768,432 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/05\/Apple-Accessibility-OS-features-2022-hero_big.jpg.large_2x.jpg?resize=680,382 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/05\/Apple-Accessibility-OS-features-2022-hero_big.jpg.large_2x.jpg?resize=1536,864 1536w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/05\/Apple-Accessibility-OS-features-2022-hero_big.jpg.large_2x.jpg?resize=50,28 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1960px) 100vw, 1960px\" \/>"caption-attachment-2322399\" class=\"wp-caption-text\">Image Credits:<\/strong> Apple<\/p><\/div><\/p>\nApple’s Sound Recognition feature will be able to be programmed to recognize sounds unique to a person’s own home, like their doorbell or appliances. The Magnifier app will add a new ML and lidar-powered Door Detection feature within a new Detection Mode section. This will help users locate a door, understand how far they are from it and describe door attributes. Apple Maps will offer sound and haptics feedback for VoiceOver users. And Apple Watch will help users control Apple Watch remotely from their paired iPhone with Apple Watch Mirroring. It also gains new Quick Action like a double-pinch gesture to answer or end a phone call, dismiss a notification, take a photo, play or pause media in the Now Playing app, and start, pause or resume a workout.<\/p>\nSnap’s platform policies for third-party apps aren’t yet fully enforced<\/h3>\n"attachment_2167646\" style=\"width: 3210px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\">"caption-attachment-2167646\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"wp-image-2167646 size-full\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/06\/snapchat-speed-blur.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"3200\" height=\"1800\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/06\/snapchat-speed-blur.jpg 3200w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/06\/snapchat-speed-blur.jpg?resize=150,84 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/06\/snapchat-speed-blur.jpg?resize=300,169 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/06\/snapchat-speed-blur.jpg?resize=768,432 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/06\/snapchat-speed-blur.jpg?resize=680,383 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/06\/snapchat-speed-blur.jpg?resize=1536,864 1536w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/06\/snapchat-speed-blur.jpg?resize=2048,1152 2048w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/06\/snapchat-speed-blur.jpg?resize=50,28 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 3200px) 100vw, 3200px\" \/>"caption-attachment-2167646\" class=\"wp-caption-text\">Image Credits:<\/strong> TechCrunch<\/p><\/div><\/p>\nA handful of Snap Kit platform developers"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/17\/snapchats-stricter-policies-for-anonymous-apps-and-friend-finders-arent-yet-fully-enforced\/\">have not yet complied<\/a> with the new guidelines around anonymous messaging and friend-finding apps"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/03\/17\/following-suicides-and-lawsuits-snapchat-restricts-apps-building-on-its-platform-with-new-policies\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">announced in March<\/a>. The Snapchat maker revamped its developer platform policies on March 17, 2022, to ban anonymous apps and require developers to build friend-finding apps to limit access to users 18 or older. The policy changes were effective immediately and existing developers were given 30 days to come into compliance \u2014 a date that would have passed last month.<\/p>\nIt is now mid-May and some developers of the newly banned and restricted apps are not yet meeting Snap\u2019s new requirements.<\/p>\nSnap confirmed to TechCrunch a small number of apps were given extensions, including anonymous apps LMK and Send It. But others seemed to be working around Snap’s ban with their friend-finding apps marketed to users ages 12+, instead of the now required 18+. They got away with this by not actually using the SDK — something impossible to tell from their App Store marketing and screenshots which imply they’re directly integrated with Snap’s features. Another app had flown under the radar, continuing to operate in violation of the rules unless TechCrunch pointed it out, resulting in a belated ban. This lack of clarity on which apps are platform apps, and which are only pretending to be, could complicate things for Snap, which is engaged in litigation over bullying-related suicides. And like all social media, the company could be under new U.S. regulation related to child safety matters in the future, as well.<\/p>\n"embed breakout\">\n"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"Bd2UjCgxsR\">"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/17\/snapchats-stricter-policies-for-anonymous-apps-and-friend-finders-arent-yet-fully-enforced\/\">Snapchat’s stricter policies for anonymous apps and friend finders aren’t yet fully enforced<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"“Snapchat’s stricter policies for anonymous apps and friend finders aren’t yet fully enforced” — TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/17\/snapchats-stricter-policies-for-anonymous-apps-and-friend-finders-arent-yet-fully-enforced\/embed\/#?secret=e39VRJvFjG#?secret=Bd2UjCgxsR\" data-secret=\"Bd2UjCgxsR\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\nTwitter deal still a go… for now<\/h3>\nFirst,"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/13\/elon-musk-twitter-deal-on-hold-spam\/\">Elon Musk tweeted<\/a> that the Twitter deal was “temporarily on hold” until Twitter could prove the percentage of spambots on its platform was actually less than 5%, as it reports. This Tuesday, he"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/17\/elon-musk-twitter-spam\/\">reiterated<\/a> the deal would not move forward until Twitter would show him proof of this <5% figure. Twitter was having none of it, though. The company filed a"https:\/\/www.sec.gov\/Archives\/edgar\/data\/0001418091\/000119312522152250\/d283119dprem14a.htm\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">\u00a0proxy statement<\/a>, saying it’s committed to the deal as agreed and is ready to close “as promptly as possible.”<\/p>\nIf Musk’s move was an"https:\/\/www.bloomberg.com\/opinion\/articles\/2022-05-17\/elon-musk-does-not-care-about-spam-bots?sref=gni836kR\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">attempt to renegotiate the price<\/a>, it didn’t seem to be working. Twitter’s top lawyer and head of policy, Vijaya Gadde, told staff at an all-hands meeting there’s “no such thing as a deal being on hold,” reported"https:\/\/www.bloomberg.com\/news\/articles\/2022-05-19\/twitter-deal-is-proceeding-not-on-hold-executives-tell-staff?sref=gni836kR\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Bloomberg<\/a>. Twitter execs also suggested that it could try to enforce the deal terms in court, if need be, but said that would be “pretty rare” for such a thing to occur. (Not that this Twitter deal is proceeding normally though!) There’s still some speculation that Musk is looking to fully back out and will find a way to do so, billion-dollar breakup fee notwithstanding. In the meantime, the bankers are"https:\/\/www.bloomberg.com\/news\/articles\/2022-05-18\/as-musk-tweets-advisers-plug-away-to-keep-twitter-deal-on-track\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">still preparing the paperwork<\/a> and execs are"https:\/\/www.bloomberg.com\/news\/articles\/2022-05-17\/twitter-loses-three-more-senior-employees-ahead-of-musk-takeover?sref=gni836kR\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">still leaving<\/a>. This week, it was Twitter Service VP Katrina Lane, head of data science Max Schmeiser and VP of product management Ilya Brown — all of whom chose to leave on their own.<\/p>\nApple\u2019s new rules let apps raise subscription prices automatically<\/h3>\n"attachment_2133289\" style=\"width: 3210px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\">"caption-attachment-2133289\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"wp-image-2133289 size-full\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/04\/app-store-2021-pattern.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"3200\" height=\"1800\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/04\/app-store-2021-pattern.jpg 3200w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/04\/app-store-2021-pattern.jpg?resize=150,84 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/04\/app-store-2021-pattern.jpg?resize=300,169 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/04\/app-store-2021-pattern.jpg?resize=768,432 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/04\/app-store-2021-pattern.jpg?resize=680,383 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/04\/app-store-2021-pattern.jpg?resize=1536,864 1536w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/04\/app-store-2021-pattern.jpg?resize=2048,1152 2048w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/04\/app-store-2021-pattern.jpg?resize=50,28 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 3200px) 100vw, 3200px\" \/>"caption-attachment-2133289\" class=\"wp-caption-text\">Image Credits:<\/strong> TechCrunch<\/p><\/div><\/p>\nAlongside the launch of the iOS 15.5 update, Apple introduced a new set of rules to govern auto-renewing subscriptions on the App Store. Now, instead of asking users to agree to any subscription price increases, developers will be able to roll out a price increase with the user\u2019s explicit consent. The feature allows developers to simply inform customers they\u2019ll be charged more, but not require the customer to opt-in to the higher pricing.<\/p>\n"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/04\/05\/apple-pilot-tests-feature-that-allows-developers-to-automatically-charge-users-for-subscription-price-increases\/\">We first broke the news that Apple was pilot testing this program<\/a> last month, when it appeared Disney+ subscription customers had simply been told their price was increasing but weren\u2019t asked for their consent. Apple then confirmed this was the result of a \u201cnew commerce feature\u201d it planned to launch soon, which it said would be \u201cgreat for both developers and users.\u201d<\/p>\nApple\u2019s position is that this could save customers the hassle of having their subscriptions automatically canceled just because they didn\u2019t see the notification or email that asked them to opt in to the price increase.<\/p>\n\u201cThis has led to some services being unintentionally interrupted for users and they must take steps to resubscribe within the app, from Settings on iPhone and iPad, or in the App Store on Mac,\u201d the company explained in its announcement on Monday.<\/p>\nHowever, the flip side of this argument is that those same customers who would have missed the consent notification will likely be the same ones who would now miss the notification informing them their subscription will be increasing in price. There\u2019s also an argument here that this change could enable unscrupulous developers and scammers to better profit from their victims if Apple doesn’t carefully enforce the program rules.<\/p>\nCurrently, those state that developers can\u2019t increase prices more than once per year. The increase also can\u2019t exceed 50% of the subscription price, and the difference in price can\u2019t exceed $5 USD per period for non-annual subscriptions or $50 USD for annual subscriptions.<\/p>\nWeekly News<\/h1>\nPlatforms: Apple<\/h3>\n\nApple"https:\/\/9to5mac.com\/2022\/05\/19\/ios-15-6-beta-1-available-public-beta-testers\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">released<\/a> the first public betas of iOS 15.6,<\/strong>\u00a0iPadOS 15.6, tvOS 15.6,"https:\/\/www.imore.com\/how-download-watchos-8-public-beta\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">watchOS 8.7<\/a> and macOS 12.5. Now"https:\/\/9to5mac.com\/2022\/05\/18\/watchos-8-7-and-tvos-15-6-betas-join-homepod-software\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">included<\/a> in the beta lineup is HomePod Software 15.6.<\/li>\nApple also released iOS 15.5 to the public,<\/strong> which included a"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/16\/ios-15-5-apple-cash-update-send-request-money-wallet\/\">new way to request and send money<\/a> from their Apple Cash card through the Wallet app, as well as a\u00a0slew of\u00a0"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/16\/apple-podcasts-gains-storage-clean-up-tools-support-for-annual-subscriptions-and-a-new-distribution-system\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">new features for the Apple Podcasts app<\/a>, and"https:\/\/appleinsider.com\/articles\/22\/05\/17\/everything-new-in-ios-155-for-iphone?utm_medium=rss\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">other features.<\/a><\/li>\nThe latest Swift Playgrounds update (ver. 4.1)<\/strong>"https:\/\/appleinsider.com\/articles\/22\/05\/17\/swift-playgrounds-update-adds-app-store-connect-integration-for-macos-users?utm_medium=rss\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">added<\/a> App Store Connect integration for macOS users.<\/li>\nApple"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/18\/apple-ad-data-brokers-privacy\/\">targeted<\/a> data brokers in its latest ad<\/strong> that promotes iOS privacy features.<\/li>\n<\/ul>\n"embed-youtube embed breakout embed--video\" style=\"text-align:center; display: block;\">"youtube-player\" width=\"640\" height=\"360\" src=\"https:\/\/www.youtube.com\/embed\/NOXK4EVFmJY?version=3&rel=1&showsearch=0&showinfo=1&iv_load_policy=1&fs=1&hl=en-US&autohide=2&wmode=transparent\" allowfullscreen=\"true\" style=\"border:0;\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts allow-same-origin allow-popups allow-presentation\"><\/iframe><\/span><\/p>\nPlatforms: Google<\/h3>\n\nGoogle Play"https:\/\/www.androidpolice.com\/google-blocking-paid-app-updates-belarus-russia\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">expanded<\/a> its app sanctions against Russia to include Belarus.<\/strong>\u00a0The company will block the download of paid apps and updates to paid apps in both Russia and Belarus, it said in an update to its"https:\/\/support.google.com\/googleplay\/android-developer\/answer\/11950272?hl=en&ref_topic=3452890\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">help article<\/a> on the matter.<\/li>\nAlongside its announcement of its new Fire 7 tablet, Amazon"https:\/\/www.aftvnews.com\/amazon-will-debut-fire-os-8-based-on-android-11-next-month\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">also revealed<\/a> that its upcoming Fire OS 8,<\/strong> its own Android-based OS, will launch in June.<\/li>\nAn update to the Google System Update changelog<\/strong> again"https:\/\/www.androidpolice.com\/google-play-services-update-set-persistent-launcher-childs-device\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">indicates that Google’s Family Link software<\/a> will allow parents to set a persistent launcher on their child’s supervised device. This would make it so that a child couldn’t change the phone’s launcher to do anything other than what’s approved. The feature hasn’t been publicly announced.<\/li>\n<\/ul>\nE-commerce and Food Delivery<\/h3>\n\nUber"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/19\/uber-grocery-outlet-pilot-on-demand-scheduled-grocery-delivery\/\">announced<\/a> a partnership with Grocery Outlet to pilot on-demand and scheduled grocery delivery.<\/strong> Initially, users can shop at 72 Grocery Outlet stores in California, Oregon and Washington state via the Uber or Uber Eats app.<\/li>\nUber also announced a whole host of new features at its"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/16\/everything-uber-announced-at-its-global-product-event\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">global product event<\/a> earlier in the week.<\/strong> Here, Uber launched an \u201cUber Travel\u201d feature that helps riders pre-book rides to and from upcoming events, like flights or restaurant reservations. It also announced an Uber Charter service for booking party buses, passenger vans and coach buses; plus event vouchers, an EV and charging map, various new Uber Eats products and additional perks for its Uber One membership; and more.<\/li>\nSnapchat and eBay announce integrations.<\/strong> Snapchat users can"https:\/\/newsroom.snap.com\/ebay-creativekit\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">now share eBay listings<\/a> with their friends using the Snapchat Camera on Android and iOS.<\/li>\nYouTube teased new features that it claims will make it easier for viewers to discover and buy from brands.<\/strong>\u00a0One new feature will allow two creators to go live at the same time to co-host a single live shopping stream. This could effectively double the draw for the event, as each creator would bring their own fanbase to the stream. Another upcoming option is called “live redirects.” With this, creators are able to start a shopping livestream on their channel, then redirect their audience over to a brand\u2019s channel for fans to keep watching. This allows brands to tap into the power of the creator\u2019s platform and reach their fanbase, but then gives the brands themselves access to that audience \u2014 and the key metrics and analytics associated with their live event \u2014 directly on their own YouTube channel.<\/li>\n<\/ul>\nFintech<\/h3>\n\nFTX US"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/19\/crypto-exchange-ftx-expands-into-stock-trading-retail-investors\/\">plans to launch<\/a> FTX Stocks, a zero-commission stock trading feature available through the FTX mobile app,<\/strong> rolling out in the U.S. in the “coming months.” The news is particularly notable given that billionaire FTX US founder Sam Bankman-Fried recently acquired a 7.6% stake in Robinhood.<\/li>\nRobinhood will launch a standalone app that"https:\/\/www.cnbc.com\/2022\/05\/17\/robinhood-to-let-users-hold-their-own-crypto-and-nfts-as-start-up-reaches-for-growth-beyond-stock-trading.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">lets users hold their own cryptocurrencies and NFTs<\/a>,<\/strong> putting it in direct competition with Coinbase and startups like MetaMask or Rainbow. The move comes at a time when Robinhood’s stocks are off by more than 70% since its IPO.<\/li>\nCoinbase"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/17\/coinbase-backtracks-hiring-plans-crypto-market-turmoil\/\">backtracked on its hiring plans<\/a>, citing the crypto market turmoil.<\/strong> The company had earlier planned to triple headcount this year, but is now reassessing its headcount needs.<\/li>\nCoinbase also said it would let a “small set” of users"https:\/\/www.coindesk.com\/business\/2022\/05\/16\/coinbase-expands-features-allowing-some-app-users-to-access-ethereum-based-dapps\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">access Ethereum-based decentralized apps<\/a> directly from its own app via the new dApp browser.<\/strong> The feature would allow users to purchase NFTs on OpenSea and Coinbase\u2019s NFT platform; trade on decentralized exchanges like Uniswap and SushiSwap; and borrow and lend through DeFi platforms like Curve and Compound.<\/li>\nPlaid, whose service powers a number of fintech aps,"https:\/\/www.protocol.com\/fintech\/plaid-identity-verification\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"> announced two products<\/a> for ACH transfers,<\/strong>\u00a0including identity verification, putting it into competition with Stripe.<\/li>\nGreenlight, a $2.3 billion fintech focused on kids,"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/17\/greenlight-fintech-focused-on-kids-launches-cash-back-credit-card-for-parents-education-savings\/\">launched a credit card for parents.<\/a><\/strong> The Greenlight-branded card, offered through Mastercard, offers up to 3% unlimited cash back on all purchases and gives parents the option to automatically invest those cash rewards in stocks and ETFs. They also can choose to invest the cash in other ways through the Greenlight mobile app or transfer funds to their bank.<\/li>\n<\/ul>\nSocial<\/h3>\n\nTikTok launched Branded Mission,"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/18\/tiktoks-ad-product-gives-creators-opportunities-partner-marketers-branded-content\/\">a new ad product<\/a> that lets advertisers crowdsource content from creators with at least 1,000 followers.<\/strong> Advertisers can launch branded campaigns by developing a brief and releasing it to the creator community, encouraging them to participate in Branded Missions. Eligible creators whose videos are selected by brands will then benefit from a cash payment and boosted traffic.<\/li>\nTikTok"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/18\/tiktok-launches-its-first-creator-crediting-tool-to-help-video-creators-cite-their-inspiration\/\">launched its first creator crediting tool<\/a> to help video creators cite their inspiration for dances, jokes, sounds and other content.<\/strong> The tool allows a creator to pick a video that’s then automatically added to their own video’s caption, linking back to the original creator. The changes follow years of complaints that top TikTok stars were lifting choreography from smaller creators, often Black creators. The problem got so bad that last year, some Black creators went on strike, refusing to create new dance moves for a recently dropped Megan Thee Stallion single as a form of protest.<\/li>\n<\/ul>\n"attachment_2320815\" style=\"width: 8010px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\">"caption-attachment-2320815\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"wp-image-2320815 size-full\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/05\/Credit-Journey.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"8000\" height=\"4500\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/05\/Credit-Journey.jpg 8000w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/05\/Credit-Journey.jpg?resize=150,84 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/05\/Credit-Journey.jpg?resize=300,169 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/05\/Credit-Journey.jpg?resize=768,432 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/05\/Credit-Journey.jpg?resize=680,383 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/05\/Credit-Journey.jpg?resize=1536,864 1536w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/05\/Credit-Journey.jpg?resize=2048,1152 2048w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/05\/Credit-Journey.jpg?resize=50,28 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 8000px) 100vw, 8000px\" \/>"caption-attachment-2320815\" class=\"wp-caption-text\">Image Credits:<\/strong> TikTok<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n\nTwitter"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/18\/twitter-rolls-out-super-follows-only-spaces\/\">rolled out the ability<\/a> for creators to host Super Follows-only Spaces as a subscriber perk.<\/strong> Subscribers globally on iOS and Android will be able to join and request to speak in Super Follows-only Spaces. (Web users can only join and listen for now.) Users who aren\u2019t Super Following a creator can still see the Space but won\u2019t be able to access it unless they subscribe.<\/li>\nSnap"https:\/\/newsroom.snap.com\/new-snap-originals-may-2022\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">announced<\/a> its new Snap Originals shows,<\/strong> which were also recently previewed at a company event. The show features stars like Simone Biles, winner of 32 Olympic and World Championship medals; NAACP Image Award winner La\u2019Ron Hines; Dixie and Charli D\u2019Amelio; and others.<\/li>\nFacebook and Twitter"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/17\/buffalo-shooting-footage-facebook-twitter-moderation\/\">struggled to contain<\/a> the Buffalo shooting video<\/strong> which was circulating across their platforms where it was being reported by end users. The New York AG also"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/18\/buffalo-shooting-twitch-discord-4chan-8chan-ny-ag\/\">announced<\/a> plans to investigate Twitch, Discord and 4chan for their role in the mass shooting.<\/li>\nSnap-owned social maps app Zenly, used by 35 million people monthly,<\/strong>"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/18\/social-maps-app-zenly-rolls-out-its-own-maps\/\">rolled out its own<\/a> mapping data and engine following last month’s redesign. The project was built using open source data from OpenStreetMap and acquired datasets from third parties. The maps feature 3D landmarks, animated effects, tiny cars, people, 3D trees and more. The new maps are live in Taipei, Tokyo, Paris, Los Angeles, New York and Seoul.<\/li>\n<\/ul>\n"attachment_2320599\" style=\"width: 2110px\" class=\"wp-caption others.<\/li>\n<\/ul>\nMessaging<\/h3>\n\nMeta"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/19\/whatsapp-ramps-up-revenue-with-global-launch-of-cloud-api-and-soon-a-paid-tier-for-its-business-app\/\">launched its free WhatsApp Cloud API<\/a>, aimed at SMBs, to all businesses worldwide <\/strong>after earlier beta testing. The API allows companies to build on top of WhatsApp to better serve their customers, but without the costs and longer integration time for the on-premise version. WhatsApp also said it would roll outpaid features for its WhatsApp Business app<\/strong> later this year, including things like the ability to manage chats across up to 10 devices. The company will also provide new customizable WhatsApp click-to-chat links that help businesses attract customers across their online presence, it said.<\/li>\nWhatsApp is also developing a feature that will allow users to stealthily exit group chats without informing the group,<\/strong> according to a leak from WABetaInfo. The feature was"https:\/\/wabetainfo.com\/whatsapp-is-working-on-silently-exit-groups\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">developed for the new Communities feature<\/a> rolling out slowly this year.<\/li>\nIndian users of the Google Messages app say"https:\/\/9to5google.com\/2022\/05\/17\/google-messages-rcs-ads-india\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">RCS is being abused<\/a> by businesses to spam users with ads,<\/strong>\u00a0with the frequency of the ads picking up over the past few months.<\/li>\nApple’s Communication Safety in Messages"https:\/\/9to5mac.com\/2022\/05\/16\/ios-15-5-communication-safety-in-messages\/#more-805790\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">expanded<\/a> to more countries<\/strong> with iOS 15.5, including Australia, Canada, New Zealand and the U.K.<\/li>\n<\/ul>\nStreaming & Entertainment<\/h3>\n\nYouTube\u2019s player"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/18\/youtubes-player-gains-new-features-including-most-replayed-video-chapters-single-loop-and-more\/\">gained new features<\/a>, including Most Replayed, Video Chapters for big-screen devices, Single Loop and more.<\/strong>\u00a0The company said it\u2019s adding a graph that people can use to easily locate and watch the most replayed parts of a video \u2014 something that could be particularly helpful for longer videos or those that haven\u2019t broken down their various sections using either timestamps or video chapters. It also rolled out Video Chapters to smart TVs and gaming consoles and an option to set a video on a looping mode.<\/li>\nApple Music"https:\/\/9to5mac.com\/2022\/05\/17\/apple-music-streaming-live\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">launched<\/a> Apple Music Live, a new recurring series that will livestream concerts from major artists, kicking off with a Harry Styles concert Friday at 9 PM ET<\/strong> alongside the release of his third album, “Harry’s House.” Encore streams will run at 12:00 PM ET on\u00a0 May 22 and 5 AM ET on May 26. Apple wouldn’t say if VOD streams would ever be available.<\/li>\nSpotify and Accenture teamed up in order to"https:\/\/newsroom.spotify.com\/2022-05-18\/spotify-and-accenture-collaborate-to-offer-spotify-premium-as-an-employee-perk\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">offer Spotify Premium as an employee perk<\/a> as part of a new offering called “Spotify for Work.”<\/strong> Accenture kicked off the deal by rolling out Spotify to its employees across Sweden, Latvia and Lithuania.<\/li>\nYouTube Music for Wear OS"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/17\/youtube-music-wear-os-stream-content-wi-fi-and-lte\/\">was updated<\/a> to allow users to stream content over Wi-Fi and LTE.<\/strong>\u00a0The feature means users will be able to listen to favorite songs even if their phone isn’t nearby.<\/li>\nCharli XCX is"https:\/\/pitchfork.com\/news\/charli-xcx-to-play-metaverse-concert-on-roblox-platform\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">scheduled<\/a> to play a “metaverse” concert on Roblox on June 17, 2022, at 7 PM ET.<\/strong> The concert will follow a five-week virtual event comprising mini-games and other digital challenges.<\/li>\nThe Apple Podcasts"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/16\/apple-podcasts-gains-storage-clean-up-tools-support-for-annual-subscriptions-and-a-new-distribution-system\/\">app gained new<\/a> storage clean-up tools, support for annual subscriptions and a new distribution system.<\/strong>\u00a0The new Apple Podcasts Delegated Delivery system will soon allow creators to more easily distribute their podcasts directly to Apple Podcasts from third-party hosting providers, including Acast, ART19, Blubrry, Buzzsprout, Libsyn, Omny Studio and RSS.com. The clean-up tools, meanwhile, will come in handy for better controlling how many episodes are saved locally and give you a chance to bulk remove downloads for the first time, including on Mac.<\/li>\n<\/ul>\nGaming<\/h3>\n\nFortnite"https:\/\/blogs.nvidia.com\/blog\/2022\/05\/19\/geforce-now-thursday-may-19\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">launched<\/a> to all iOS users via Nvidia’s GeForce Now cloud gaming service<\/strong> after a few months of closed beta trials. The launch means iPhone users have yet another workaround to play the popular game on their device, despite its ban from the App Store, following Fortnite’s launch on Microsoft’s Cloud Gaming service earlier this month.<\/li>\nA report from"https:\/\/www.reuters.com\/technology\/exclusive-tiktok-plans-big-push-into-gaming-conducting-tests-vietnam-sources-2022-05-19\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Reuters<\/a> said TikTok was testing HTML5 games in Vietnam, but TikTok"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/19\/tiktok-is-gearing-up-for-games-including-interactive-minigames-for-tiktok-live\/\">told<\/a> TechCrunch that was inaccurate — no games were currently testing in that market.<\/strong> However, the company had previously"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/11\/09\/tiktok-ventures-into-mobile-gaming-initially-in-partnership-with-zynga\/\">confirmed<\/a> it was engaged in further gaming partnership discussions after its Zynga deal was announced.<\/li>\nTechCrunch"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/19\/tiktok-is-gearing-up-for-games-including-interactive-minigames-for-tiktok-live\/\">also reported and confirmed<\/a> a separate effort focused on bringing interactive minigames — like “Draw & Guess” — to the TikTok LIVE platform.<\/strong><\/li>\nNiantic\u2019s Pok\u00e9mon GO"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/19\/pokemon-go-amazon-prime-gaming-bonus\/\">partnered<\/a> with"https:\/\/gaming.amazon.com\/loot\/pokemongo\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Amazon Prime Gaming<\/a> and Prime Student to offer exclusive bonus item bundles every two weeks to Prime members.<\/strong> Users can log in to Prime and get a code, which they can redeem on Niantic\u2019s rewards page. The items will then appear in the game.<\/li>\n<\/ul>\nSecurity & Privacy<\/h3>\n\nBrave’s iOS web browser was updated"https:\/\/brave.com\/1.38-release-ios\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">with a new Privacy Hub feature<\/a> <\/strong>that offers users more visibility on exactly what Brave blocked, and how Brave protects your personal information online. It does so by showing a rolling update of how many trackers Brave blocked on a specific site, or in a given time span. The hub also offers education about trackers and privacy threats.<\/li>\nApple"https:\/\/9to5mac.com\/2022\/05\/16\/apple-patches-27-security-flaws-ios-15-5\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">patched<\/a> almost 30 security flaws with iOS 15.5,<\/strong> as well as over 50 fixes for macOS 12.4.<\/li>\n<\/ul>\nFunding and M&A<\/h1>\n\ud83d\udcb0 Pintarnya, a startup building a super app for Indonesia\u2019s blue-collar workers,"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/18\/pintarnya-is-building-a-super-app-for-indonesias-blue-collar-workers\/\">raised $6.3 million<\/a> in seed funding<\/strong> led by Sequoia Capital India and General Catalyst. The funding includes a $100,000 grant from Sequoia Spark, a program for women founders. The app offers verified job postings and financial services, like loans, for blue-collar workers.<\/p>\n\ud83d\udcb0 Instant delivery app Gopuff, valued at $15 billion,"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/18\/gopuff-the-instant-delivery-upstart-taps-ex-disney-head-bob-iger-as-its-newest-investor-and-advisor\/\">announced<\/a> a new advisor and investor: Bob Iger, the former CEO and chairman of The Walt Disney Company.<\/strong> The company wouldn’t say if the investment was coming as a separate investment, or as part of a $1 billion round (in debt and equity) that the company is in the process of closing.<\/p>\n\ud83d\udcb0 Instabug, a startup that helps mobile developers monitor, identify and fix bugs within apps,"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/17\/instabug-lands-46m-to-help-keep-your-apps-from-crashing\/\">raised $46 million<\/a> in Series B funding led by Insight Partners.<\/strong> The company said its ARR doubled in 2021 and the number of enterprise customers grew 10x, as it added new clients like DoorDash, Verizon, Qualtrics, Porsche and Gojek. Last year, its software sat within 2.7 billion mobile devices, processed 110 billion mobile sessions (up at least 20x from 2020) and helped customers resolve 4.2 billion issues, it said.<\/p>\n\ud83d\udcb0 Unit, a banking-as-a-service startup that allows developers to easily build new fintech apps,"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/17\/banking-as-a-service-startup-unit-closes-on-100m-at-a-1-2b-valuation\/\">raised $100 million<\/a> in Series C funding led by Insight Partners, at a $1.2 billion valuation.<\/strong> Unit said its transaction volume grew 7x over the past six months and has crossed an annualized transaction volume of $2.6 billion. It’s also issued over 430,000 cards to over 330,000 customers and saw a 10x increase in deposit volumes.<\/p>\n<\/p>\n"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/this-week-in-apps\/\">"lazy\" class=\"aligncenter size-large wp-image-1952542\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/02\/this-week-in-apps-banner2.png?w=680\" alt=\"\" width=\"680\" height=\"93\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/02\/this-week-in-apps-banner2.png 2047w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/02\/this-week-in-apps-banner2.png?resize=150,21 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/02\/this-week-in-apps-banner2.png?resize=300,41 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/02\/this-week-in-apps-banner2.png?resize=768,105 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/02\/this-week-in-apps-banner2.png?resize=680,93 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/02\/this-week-in-apps-banner2.png?resize=1536,210 1536w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/02\/this-week-in-apps-banner2.png?resize=50,7 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 680px) 100vw, 680px\" \/><\/a><\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"Welcome back to This Week in Apps, the weekly TechCrunch series that recaps the latest in mobile OS news, mobile applications and the overall app economy. is drafting their own startup Black Swan memo"},"content":{"rendered":""speakable-summary\">Welcome to Startups Weekly, a fresh, human-first take on this week\u2019s startup news and trends. To get this in your inbox,"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/newsletters\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">subscribe here.<\/a><\/em><\/p>\n\u201cYou can often pick up significant market share in an economic downturn by just staying alive,\u201d top startup accelerator Y Combinator"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/19\/yc-advises-founders-to-plan-for-the-worst\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">wrote in an internal e-mail to its founders this week.<\/a> The advice was one of ten bullet points in a memo meant to help companies navigate the economic"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/06\/startup-tech-layoffs-in-may\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">downturn crushing tech. <\/a>Other stand-out quotes include \u201cplan for the worst\u201d and \u201cno one can predict how bad the economy will get, but things don\u2019t look good.\u201d<\/p>\nThe email is a vibe shift from"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/03\/29\/everything-you-need-to-know-about-y-combinators-winter-2022-demo-day-part-1\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">just a few weeks ago<\/a>, when hundreds of Y Combinator startups \u2014 many of which already raised venture funding \u2014 presented themselves to the public on Demo Day. The startups were the first to receive Y Combinator\u2019s new $500,000 standard check and were aggressively focused on international opportunity. Now, YC is saying that \u201cthis slow down will have a disproportionate impact on international companies,\u201d among others.<\/p>\n"embed breakout\">\n"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"EEuPjm05EG\">"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/19\/yc-advises-founders-to-plan-for-the-worst\/\">YC advises founders to ‘plan for the worst’ amid market teardown<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"“YC advises founders to ‘plan for the worst’ amid market teardown” — TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/19\/yc-advises-founders-to-plan-for-the-worst\/embed\/#?secret=3jScHFeycU#?secret=EEuPjm05EG\" data-secret=\"EEuPjm05EG\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\nWhile Y Combinator\u2019s memo wasn\u2019t meant to be public, it isn\u2019t the only one publishing a Black Swan Memo in preparation for what\u2019s to come. TechCrunch obtained a series of memos that venture capitalist firms sent to portfolio companies about the market downturn. Some were hopeful, some were simple, and others were a vibe check as straightforward as, Can you tell us your ARR and cash-burn in writing? Pretty please?<\/p>\nI explored this topic in my most recent TechCrunch+ column,"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/21\/investor-advice-for-startups-2022-market-downturn\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">\u201cIt’s not business as usual (and investors are admitting it).”<\/a> Subscribe to"https:\/\/podcasts.apple.com\/us\/podcast\/equity\/id1215439780\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"> Equity<\/a> for a podcast version of this conversation next week as well! In the rest of this newsletter, we\u2019ll address more layoffs at tech companies, ghosts showing up to $44 billion dates, and Swyft startups. As always, you can support me by forwarding this newsletter to a friend or"https:\/\/twitter.com\/nmasc_\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">following me on Twitter<\/a> or"https:\/\/natasha.substack.com\/publish\/subscribers\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">my blog.<\/a><\/p>\nSo. Many. Layoffs. <\/strong><\/h2>\nMay\u2019s mad month of layoffs continues. Amanda and I wrote up a"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/20\/startup-tech-layoff-may-week-3\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"> third installment of tech layoffs <\/a>that rippled across all industries and stages. Employees from Section4, Carvana, DataRobot, Mural, Robinhood, On Deck, Thrasio, MainStreet and Netflix have been impacted by the workforce reductions. Some bigger companies are instituting hiring freezes, such as Twitter and Meta, or announcing a shift in strategy, such as Uber.<\/p>"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\nHere\u2019s why it\u2019s important: <\/strong>At time of publication, employees from Picsart, Netflix, Cars24 and Skillz were impacted by this week\u2019s wave of reductions. It tells us who is vulnerable from a business model perspective \u2014 such as subscription-based businesses and marketplaces \u2014 and that companies may start to conduct more than one round of layoffs in the same month (cough, cough, Netflix).<\/p>\n\n"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/16\/how-quickly-are-startup-layoffs-accelerating\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">How quickly are startup layoffs accelerating?<\/a><\/li>\n"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/13\/startup-tech-layoff-and-hiring-freeze-in-may\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Tech employees face another tough week of cross-stage layoffs<\/a><\/li>\n"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/17\/coinbase-backtracks-hiring-plans-crypto-market-turmoil\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Coinbase backtracks on its hiring plans, citing crypto market turmoil<\/a><\/li>\n<\/ul>\n"attachment_2237095\" style=\"width: 1742px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\">"caption-attachment-2237095\" loading=\"lazy\" this<\/strong><\/h2>\n"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/20\/a-twitter-bot-wrote-this-for-elon-musk\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">On Equity this week<\/a>, your favorite podcast trio spoke about unicorn vibes, property ownership tech plays and, as you can tell by the headline, the latest in the Elon Musk Twitter story. At this point, we’re deciding if it’s even worth trying to keep track of the timeline.<\/p>\nHere’s why it’s important:<\/strong> Our weekly digest of tech news is a good way to track the big news items that shape this wonky landscape, and stay aware of deals that may have flown under your radar. In this case, we spent the biggest chunk of time deciding"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/20\/a-twitter-bot-wrote-this-for-elon-musk\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">why Elon Musk is ghosting the $44 billion date <\/a>that he made with Twitter. The answer, not so complicatedly, seems because he’s more interested in chasing than cuffing.<\/p>\nAfter we recorded our episode, more news about Elon Musk emerged from an investigation"https:\/\/www.businessinsider.com\/spacex-paid-250000-to-a-flight-attendant-who-accused-elon-musk-of-sexual-misconduct-2022-5\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"> by Business Insider.<\/a> Allegedly, Elon Musk exposed himself to a SpaceX flight attendant and propositioned her for sex. The company paid $250,000 for her silence, Business Insider reports. Musk has since"https:\/\/www.cnn.com\/2022\/05\/20\/tech\/elon-musk-sexual-harassment-denies-allegations\/index.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">denied<\/a> the harassment claims.
"https:\/\/www.businessinsider.com\/spacex-paid-250000-to-a-flight-attendant-who-accused-elon-musk-of-sexual-misconduct-2022-5\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Read the entire story here.<\/a><\/p>\n"attachment_2240211\" style=\"width: 2130px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\">"caption-attachment-2240211\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"wp-image-2240211 size-full\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/11\/GettyImages-1282121809.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"2120\" height=\"1414\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/11\/GettyImages-1282121809.jpg 2120w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/11\/GettyImages-1282121809.jpg?resize=150,100 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/11\/GettyImages-1282121809.jpg?resize=300,200 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/11\/GettyImages-1282121809.jpg?resize=768,512 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/11\/GettyImages-1282121809.jpg?resize=680,454 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/11\/GettyImages-1282121809.jpg?resize=1536,1024 1536w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/11\/GettyImages-1282121809.jpg?resize=2048,1366 2048w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/11\/GettyImages-1282121809.jpg?resize=50,33 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 2120px) 100vw, 2120px\" \/>"caption-attachment-2240211\" class=\"wp-caption-text\">Image Credits:<\/strong> Westend61 \/ Getty Images<\/p><\/div><\/p>\nDeal of the week<\/strong><\/h2>\n"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/19\/swyft-cities-is-the-winner-of-the-techcrunch-mobility-2022-pitch-off\/?cx_testId=6&cx_testVariant=cx_undefined&cx_artPos=2#cxrecs_s\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Swyft Cities!<\/a> The Mountain View\u2013based company, built by Google alums, wants to improve transportation and offer a lower-cost-per-mile vehicle with a smaller carbon emission footprint. The solution looks like an autonomous, lightweight, fixed-cable vehicle. The startup is the winner of the TechCrunch Sessions: Mobility 2022 pitch-off, with Beyond Aero as the runner-up.<\/p>\nHere\u2019s why it\u2019s important:<\/strong> Swyft has checked off a lot of \u2018we\u2019re not flailing\u201d boxes. Alongside a MVP and debut customer agreement, the company set up a R&D center in Christchurch, New Zealand. It also works with Remarkables Park in Queenstown, a large office, retail and residential space, to develop a network of autonomous gondolas,"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/19\/swyft-cities-is-the-winner-of-the-techcrunch-mobility-2022-pitch-off\/?cx_testId=6&cx_testVariant=cx_undefined&cx_artPos=2#cxrecs_s\">TechCrunch reports.<\/a> It plans to be up and running by August 2024.<\/p>\n\n"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/19\/belong-secures-80m-in-equity-debt-to-take-the-pain-out-of-rental-property-management\/\" -companies?tags=26402"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=26402"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=26402"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":8611,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/market\/","name":"market","slug":"market","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/8611"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=8611"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=8611"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=8611"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=8611"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":414,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/mobility\/","name":"mobility","slug":"mobility","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/414"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=414"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=414"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=414"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=414"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":4621,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/startup\/","name":"startup","slug":"startup","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/4621"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=4621"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=4621"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=4621"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=4621"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2322515,"date":"2022-05-21T10:01:53","date_gmt":"2022-05-21T17:01:53","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2322515"},"modified":"2022-05-20T12:27:02","modified_gmt":"2022-05-20T19:27:02","slug":"europes-deep-tech-depends-on-university-spinouts","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/21\/europes-deep-tech-depends-on-university-spinouts\/","title":{"rendered":"Europe’s deep tech depends on university spinouts"},"content":{"rendered":""speakable-summary\">"featured__span-first-words\">Welcome to The<\/span> TechCrunch Exchange, a weekly startups-and-markets newsletter. It\u2019s inspired by the <\/em>"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/the-exchange\/\">daily TechCrunch+ column<\/em><\/a>where it gets its name. Want it in your inbox every Saturday? Sign up <\/em>"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/newsletters\">here<\/em><\/a>.<\/em><\/p>\nDeep tech has become a hot topic in Europe, with hopes that the region can have an edge over the rest of the world for innovation rooted in fundamental research. One of the key arguments: European countries have great universities and talent. But how can academic talent translate into startups? Let’s dive in. \u2014"https:\/\/twitter.com\/abracarioca\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Anna<\/a><\/p>\nUniversities, a deep tech cauldron<\/h2>\n“From startups to universities, we join forces to make Europe a world leader in the new wave of deep tech innovation!” European commissioner Mariya Gabriel"https:\/\/twitter.com\/gabrielmariya\/status\/1526526944778518535\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">tweeted<\/a> earlier this week after her talk at the Tech.eu Summit in Brussels. As I noticed while attending the event, she was far from the only one to mention this topic enthusiastically.<\/p>\nThat deep tech raises high hopes in Europe wasn’t exactly a surprise.
"https:\/\/twitter.com\/alex\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Alex<\/a> and I already wrote about"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/02\/17\/why-you-shouldnt-ignore-europes-deep-tech-boom\/\">Europe’s deep tech boom<\/a> and"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/02\/24\/vcs-weigh-in-on-europes-future-in-the-critical-deep-tech-market\/\">investor interest in it<\/a> earlier this year. But the role that educational institutions are expected to play piqued my interest.<\/p>\n"embed breakout\">\n"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"uoF1trkm7i\">"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/02\/24\/vcs-weigh-in-on-europes-future-in-the-critical-deep-tech-market\/\">VCs weigh in on Europe\u2019s future in the critical deep tech market<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"“VCs weigh in on Europe\u2019s future in the critical deep tech market” — TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/02\/24\/vcs-weigh-in-on-europes-future-in-the-critical-deep-tech-market\/embed\/#?secret=UMVkW02Slj#?secret=uoF1trkm7i\" data-secret=\"uoF1trkm7i\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n“There is no doubt that the future of innovation in Europe will emerge from its world-leading universities,” Riam Kanso wrote in a"https:\/\/tech.eu\/2022\/04\/13\/how-training-phd-students-in-deeptech-entrepreneurship-can-spur-european-innovation\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Tech.eu guest post<\/a> ahead of the event. Kanso is the founder of"https:\/\/conceptionx.org\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Conception X<\/a>, which I had coincidentally heard about for the first time"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/03\/deal-flow-newsletter-preseed-now-to-introduce-future-uk-crown-jewels-to-investors\/\">earlier this month<\/a>. The U.K.-based nonprofit aims to transform Ph.D. researchers into venture scientists.<\/p>\n“It\u2019s a simple but well-proven recipe,” Kanso said. “You have a Ph.D. team working on cutting-edge research with key real-world applications. They know their innovation could help discover effective treatments for now-incurable diseases, power up carbon-negative cities or tackle the future of automation. Through a combination of entrepreneurship training, access to pro-bono legal advice, funding opportunities and expert connections, we help them figure out how to turn their research into a viable deep tech startup.”<\/p>\nIt isn’t a new thing for universities to more or less willingly give birth to spinoffs or spinouts (we will use the terms interchangeably here.) MIT, for instance, is famous for counting"https:\/\/en.wikipedia.org\/wiki\/List_of_companies_founded_by_Massachusetts_Institute_of_Technology_alumni\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">many entrepreneurs<\/a> among its alumni, and quite a few of these ventures are based on intellectual property developed during their studies or research.<\/p>\nBut in Europe, intellectual property can be a thorny issue. The “potential for meaningful innovation brewing across Europe\u2019s research labs,” Kanso said, “largely remains untapped due to varying \u2014 and at times"https:\/\/sifted.eu\/articles\/university-tech-transfer-overhaul\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">stifling<\/a> \u2014 IP ownership rules that can make spinout companies uninvestable and hard to scale.”<\/p>\nIncreasingly though, both European universities and venture capital firms are making efforts to make sure the most promising seeds turn into successful companies.<\/p>\nMind the gap<\/h2>\nDespite the hurdles, VCs looking for innovation know that spinouts are very much worth their attention. “As an investor in early-stage businesses, many with a deeply technical nature, we see universities as foundational to the companies we invest in,” said Simon King, himself a VC with a Ph.D.

Exchange newsletter","slug":"techcrunch-exchange-newsletter","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/576936589"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=576936589"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=576936589"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=576936589"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=576936589"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":576765839,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/the-exchange\/","name":"The Exchange","slug":"the-exchange","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/576765839"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=576765839"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=576765839"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=576765839"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=576765839"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2322684,"date":"2022-05-21T10:00:24","date_gmt":"2022-05-21T17:00:24","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2322684"},"modified":"2022-05-21T11:22:45","modified_gmt":"2022-05-21T18:22:45","slug":"lightspeed-venture-partners-investor-mercedes-bent-metaverse-hype","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/21\/lightspeed-venture-partners-investor-mercedes-bent-metaverse-hype\/","title":{"rendered":"Lightspeed’s Mercedes Bent on why the metaverse isn’t overhyped"},"content":{"rendered":""speakable-summary\">On the"https:\/\/podcasts.apple.com\/us\/podcast\/chain-reaction\/id1616008890\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Chain Reaction<\/a> podcast this week, we dove into a topic that tends to stir up strong emotions, even from those outside the crypto space — the metaverse. Mercedes Bent, an investor at Lightspeed Venture Partners who focuses on consumer investments in crypto, joined us to unpack this loaded term and explain why she sees its potential.<\/p>\n“It’s become like a punching bag,” Bent told TechCrunch. “If you think about the potential of it, and why maybe a geek like me gets excited about it, it’s because there are things you can do [in the metaverse] that you could not do in the real world.”<\/p>\n"https:\/\/player.simplecast.com\/6c95a13b-acfb-478d-9707-30750d5d461f?dark=false\" width=\"100%\" height=\"200px\" frameborder=\"no\" scrolling=\"no\" seamless=\"\"><\/iframe><\/p>\nThe prospect of attending an event with tens of thousands of other attendees across the world in the metaverse, for example, excites Bent. But even more than entertainment, Bent is enthusiastic about the potential for the metaverse to have an impact through education. She shared the hypothetical example of public school students being able to learn from the best instructors in the world in a metaverse similar to the movie Ready Player One — though without the dystopian elements, she qualified. Bent’s vision squares up with some of her non-crypto consumer investments at Lightspeed, such as small-group live education platform"https:\/\/lsvp.com\/portfolio\/outschool\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Outschool<\/a>.<\/p>\nBut what will the metaverse actually look like? When we asked Bent, who once worked for virtual reality technology company Upload, she said she used to think the metaverse had to be tied to VR technology, specifically the head-mounted display screen.<\/p>\nShe’s since realized that what the metaverse has to offer has less to do with how users access it physically and more to do with the sense of community it can foster.<\/p>\n“I think what this era — the 2021 and 2022 era of the metaverse terminology — has shown is that it’s not about the headset, it’s not about what physical apparatus you use, it’s about the sense of [a] collective being together, and presence,” she added.<\/p>"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\nWhile VR tech itself has been around for decades, Bent posits that the metaverse gained traction as a concept last year because it offered one thing classic VR games like Second Life did not — the ability to transfer in-game currency to fiat currency. Cryptocurrency, she believes, made that switch possible.<\/p>\n“There was obviously in-game currency and there were obviously virtual goods you could buy before, but the ability to be able to transfer that to fiat and then go use it in the real world to pay your rent bill is just something entirely different that we didn’t have in such a mass quantity before,” Bent said.<\/p>\nThat technological development coupled with the onset of the pandemic, which gave people the opportunity to spend more time online, gave the metaverse new life, she continued.<\/p>\nSkeptics think the metaverse gets a lot of hype and isn’t backed by substantial technology or user adoption. Bent said that in her experience, skepticism is to be expected for any early-stage consumer products.<\/p>\n“These hyped areas look really nonobvious. I mean, they don’t have traction, they’re just an idea. They’re often from a founder who hasn’t necessarily had the most pedigree, so you have to kind of take a leap of faith,” Bent said. Bent’s mission as an investor is to back “early stage consumer companies that are unlocking wealth creation for underserved individuals and regions,” according to her website — a thesis that might help explain where she finds some of that faith.<\/p>\nAs an early-stage consumer investor, Bent pushes back on the idea that it’s too early to fund consumer-facing crypto companies that haven’t yet honed their user experience.<\/p>\n“There are not very many companies [in web3] that I would say have scaled to what I would call a mass audience yet. We have Metamask, which is pretty far along, but I think all of these companies are up for grabs in terms of [whether] somebody else could come along to replace them,” Bent said. “I think we’re going to see the next WhatsApp, AOL, and Google founded in short order.”<\/p>\n"embed breakout\">\n"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"nehAIR6VLp\">"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/19\/blockchain-billionaire-sam-bankman-fried-big-bet-robinhood-chain-reaction\/\">A blockchain billionaire’s big bet<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"“A blockchain billionaire’s big bet” — TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/19\/blockchain-billionaire-sam-bankman-fried-big-bet-robinhood-chain-reaction\/embed\/#?secret=y8X6xbCV7I#?secret=nehAIR6VLp\" data-secret=\"nehAIR6VLp\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n"article-content\">\nSubscribe to Chain Reaction on\u00a0"https:\/\/podcasts.apple.com\/us\/podcast\/chain-reaction\/id1616008890\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Apple<\/a>,\u00a0"https:\/\/open.spotify.com\/show\/6dC9jw0YyPqnul5P3CECoN\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Spotify<\/a> or your alternative podcast platform of choice to keep up with us every week.<\/em><\/p>\n<\/div>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"On the Chain Reaction podcast this week, we dove into a topic that tends to stir up strong emotions, even from those outside the crypto space — the metaverse. Mercedes Bent, an investor at Lightspeed Venture Partners who focuses on consumer investments in crypto, joined us to unpack this loaded term and explain why she
