/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=51541356"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=51541356"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=51541356"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":39170,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/edtech\/","name":"edtech","slug":"edtech","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/39170"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=39170"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=39170"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=39170"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=39170"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":449557078,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/education\/","name":"Education","slug":"education","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/449557078"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=449557078"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=449557078"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=449557078"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=449557078"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":576796013,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/futurism\/","name":"futurism","slug":"futurism","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/576796013"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=576796013"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=576796013"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=576796013"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=576796013"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":449557080,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/gaming\/","name":"Gaming","slug":"gaming","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/449557080"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=449557080"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=449557080"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=449557080"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=449557080"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":81,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/google\/","name":"Google","slug":"google","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/81"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=81"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=81"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=81"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=81"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2318632,"date":"2022-05-21T07:00:37","date_gmt":"2022-05-21T14:00:37","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2318632"},"modified":"2022-05-19T13:00:09","modified_gmt":"2022-05-19T20:00:09","slug":"premium-streaming-subscriptions-continue-to-increase-despite-netflix-tribulations","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/21\/premium-streaming-subscriptions-continue-to-increase-despite-netflix-tribulations\/","title":{"rendered":"Premium streaming subscriptions continue to increase despite Netflix’s downfall"},"content":{"rendered":""speakable-summary\">If you\u2019ve been following Netflix lately, then you\u2019d know the streamer is on shaky ground at the moment.
"https:\/\/www.antenna.live\/post\/netflix-q122-retrospective\">Antenna<\/a> data reveals that Netflix saw 3.6 million subscription cancellations in the first quarter of 2022, over one million more than the company experienced in Q1 2021 and Q4 2021. This is a significant indicator that Netflix is inching closer to losing its top spot in the streaming battle.<\/p>\nWhile Netflix’s downfall has raised speculations about if the SVOD (subscription video on demand) industry has peaked and is beginning a downward trend, new Antenna data supports the contrary.<\/p>\nAntenna discovered that U.S. Subscriptions in the Premium SVOD category grew +4.0% quarter-over-quarter and by +24.7% year-over-year. The research also shows that there were 37.4 million new gross SVOD customers and a loss of 29.8 million subscribers, leaving a gross of just 7.7 million new subscribers in the first quarter of 2022.<\/p>\n"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/05\/Screen-Shot-2022-05-13-at-12.54.44-PM.png\">"lazy\" class=\"size-large wp-image-2318637\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/05\/Screen-Shot-2022-05-13-at-12.54.44-PM.png?w=680\" alt=\"\" width=\"680\" height=\"343\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/05\/Screen-Shot-2022-05-13-at-12.54.44-PM.png 919w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/05\/Screen-Shot-2022-05-13-at-12.54.44-PM.png?resize=150,76 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/05\/Screen-Shot-2022-05-13-at-12.54.44-PM.png?resize=300,151 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/05\/Screen-Shot-2022-05-13-at-12.54.44-PM.png?resize=768,388 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/05\/Screen-Shot-2022-05-13-at-12.54.44-PM.png?resize=680,343 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/05\/Screen-Shot-2022-05-13-at-12.54.44-PM.png?resize=50,25 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 680px) 100vw, 680px\" \/><\/a><\/p>\n"attachment_2318635\" style=\"width: 690px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\">"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/05\/antenna-streaming-1536x768-1.webp\">"caption-attachment-2318635\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-large wp-image-2318635\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/05\/antenna-streaming-1536x768-1.webp?w=680\" alt=\"\" width=\"680\" height=\"340\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/05\/antenna-streaming-1536x768-1.webp 1536w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/05\/antenna-streaming-1536x768-1.webp?resize=150,75 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/05\/antenna-streaming-1536x768-1.webp?resize=300,150 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/05\/antenna-streaming-1536x768-1.webp?resize=768,384 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/05\/antenna-streaming-1536x768-1.webp?resize=680,340 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/05\/antenna-streaming-1536x768-1.webp?resize=50,25 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 680px) 100vw, 680px\" \/><\/a>"caption-attachment-2318635\" class=\"wp-caption-text\">Image Credits:<\/strong> Antenna<\/p><\/div><\/p>\nThe 37.4 number is consistent with the past two quarters yet significantly higher than 2019 (before Covid-19). The growth was largely driven by fledgling services Peacock and Paramount+, which added a combined 6.1 million or more U.S. Subscribers.<\/p>\nIn comparison, in 2019, when the market was dominated by Netflix and Hulu (services like Disney+, Peacock, and HBO Max didn\u2019t exist yet), there were a total of 10.3 million subscriptions in the year\u2019s first quarter. The massive increase depicts a three-year compound annual growth rate of 54%.<\/p>"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\nWhile subscriber growth may be high right now, so are cancellations. There were just under 30 million cancellations in Q1 2022, which is 12% higher than any quarter in history, or 4.5 times the cancel volume seen three years prior, Antenna finds.<\/p>\nThe cancellations may not be anything to worry about since the new subscriber additions indicate consumers are bouncing around– also known as churn and return. Paramount+, Peacock, and Disney+ accounted for 51% of all new sign-ups in the quarter. Plus, the three mentioned services made up a large portion of new sign-ups for the churned Q1 2022 Netflix users.<\/p>\n"attachment_2319105\" style=\"width: 690px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\">"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/05\/Screen-Shot-2022-05-16-at-11.49.36-AM.png\">"caption-attachment-2319105\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-large wp-image-2319105\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/05\/Screen-Shot-2022-05-16-at-11.49.36-AM.png?w=680\" alt=\"\" width=\"680\" height=\"346\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/05\/Screen-Shot-2022-05-16-at-11.49.36-AM.png 918w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/05\/Screen-Shot-2022-05-16-at-11.49.36-AM.png?resize=150,76 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/05\/Screen-Shot-2022-05-16-at-11.49.36-AM.png?resize=300,153 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/05\/Screen-Shot-2022-05-16-at-11.49.36-AM.png?resize=768,391 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/05\/Screen-Shot-2022-05-16-at-11.49.36-AM.png?resize=680,346 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/05\/Screen-Shot-2022-05-16-at-11.49.36-AM.png?resize=50,25 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 680px) 100vw, 680px\" \/><\/a>"caption-attachment-2319105\" class=\"wp-caption-text\">Image Credits:<\/strong> Antenna<\/p><\/div><\/p>\nPeter Fondulas, principal at Hub,"https:\/\/www.tvtechnology.com\/news\/new-research-suggests-the-streaming-party-isnt-over\">stated<\/a>, \u201cNetflix\u2019s subscriber loss in Q1 of 2022, and its anticipated losses in the following quarters, represent a tiny proportion of its global subscriber base. And in fact, at some point, a service as widely penetrated as Netflix has only so much room left to grow. In our view, it would be a grave mistake to take the Netflix experience as a sign that streaming TV services are on the verge of decline, as some analysts have suggested. The lure of buzzworthy exclusive content, and the sheer convenience of on-demand viewing, are two powerful forces that should keep these services growing at least for the near term.\u201d<\/p>\nIn Q1 2022, Netflix reported a"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/04\/19\/netflix-shares-down-more-than-20-after-losing-200000-subscribers-in-first-quarter\/\">loss of 200,000 subscribers<\/a>, making its first subscriber loss in more than ten years. The decline brought Netflix\u2019s subscriber base to 221.6 million, down from 221.8 million in the previous quarter. The losses will only continue, according to Netflix forecasts, and the streamer is expected to lose 2 million in the second quarter.<\/p>\nSince Netflix raised prices on all its plan tiers domestically in"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/01\/14\/netflix-raised-its-prices-again\/\">January 2022<\/a>, there has been a major jump in subscription cancellations. The Netflix U.S. active monthly churn rate was a little over 2% in"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2019\/01\/15\/netflix-price-hike\/\">January 2019<\/a>, after it raised subscription prices.<\/p>\nFurther,"https:\/\/www.antenna.live\/post\/double-click-on-netflix-q122-churned-users\">Antenna<\/a> data shows that Netflix’s active monthly churn rate increased +0.95pts month-over-month in January 2022, where a price jump led to an active monthly churn rate of 3%. By the end of March, Netflix’s active monthly churn rate was 3.3%. This suggests that Netflix’s upcoming"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/10\/netflix-could-introduce-its-ad-supported-plan-as-soon-as-this-year\/\">cheaper ad-supported tier<\/a> is the company’s plan to minimize churn.<\/p>\n"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/05\/Screen-Shot-2022-05-13-at-12.54.35-PM.png\">"lazy\" class=\"size-large wp-image-2319103\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/05\/Screen-Shot-2022-05-13-at-12.54.35-PM.png?w=680\" alt=\"\" width=\"680\" height=\"347\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/05\/Screen-Shot-2022-05-13-at-12.54.35-PM.png 921w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/05\/Screen-Shot-2022-05-13-at-12.54.35-PM.png?resize=150,77 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/05\/Screen-Shot-2022-05-13-at-12.54.35-PM.png?resize=300,153 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/05\/Screen-Shot-2022-05-13-at-12.54.35-PM.png?resize=768,392 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/05\/Screen-Shot-2022-05-13-at-12.54.35-PM.png?resize=680,347 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/05\/Screen-Shot-2022-05-13-at-12.54.35-PM.png?resize=50,26 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 680px) 100vw, 680px\" \/><\/a><\/p>\nAll this data goes to show how volatile the streaming market is. It’s hard to predict which service will be on top next, but established streamers like Netflix need to be on their toes and come up with new strategies to attract new subscribers.<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"If you\u2019ve been following Netflix lately, then you\u2019d know the streamer is on shaky ground at the moment. This is a significant indicator that Netflix Media","slug":"streaming-media","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/71325"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=71325"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=71325"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=71325"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=71325"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2322082,"date":"2022-05-21T07:00:13","date_gmt":"2022-05-21T14:00:13","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2322082"},"modified":"2022-05-20T10:02:21","modified_gmt":"2022-05-20T17:02:21","slug":"a-weaker-economy-wont-solve-the-tech-talent-crunch-overnight","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/21\/a-weaker-economy-wont-solve-the-tech-talent-crunch-overnight\/","title":{"rendered":"A weaker economy won\u2019t solve the tech talent crunch overnight"},"content":{"rendered":""speakable-summary\">"featured__span-first-words\">As bad economic<\/span> news piles up seemingly"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/16\/how-quickly-are-startup-layoffs-accelerating\/\">on a daily basis<\/a>, we don\u2019t know what"https:\/\/www.cnbc.com\/2022\/04\/28\/us-q1-gdp-growth.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">the future holds<\/a> except that change is on the way. Although we are seeing layoffs and"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/13\/startup-tech-layoff-and-hiring-freeze-in-may\/\">hiring freezes<\/a> at some companies, it doesn\u2019t necessarily mean the talent crunch will immediately abate.<\/p>\nThere will likely be some lag before we start to see"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/02\/23\/recruit-retain-resign-re-skill-repeat\/\">the tight job market<\/a> we\u2019ve experienced for the last couple of years begin to loosen. Even then, there are certain fields like engineering, data science and"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/02\/10\/5-ways-to-attract-top-cybersecurity-talent-in-a-tight-labor-market\/\">cybersecurity<\/a>, where tech companies large and small could still struggle to find talent no matter what the macroeconomic conditions look like.<\/p>\nOver the last month, we have seen an increase in the number of"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/06\/startup-tech-layoffs-in-may\/\">startup layoff announcements<\/a> at companies like Cameo, On Deck and Robinhood. Meanwhile, big companies like Netflix, Meta and Uber have announced hiring freezes, with the consumer streaming service throwing"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/17\/netflix-lays-off-150-staffers-citing-slowing-revenue-growth\/\">some layoffs<\/a> into the mix as well.<\/p>\nDespite this onslaught of bad news, for now, most startup founders, investors and HR pros don\u2019t see the job market magically improving for hiring departments, at least in the near term. That means the folks in charge of hiring are still going to have to shake the bushes for talent.<\/p>\nMatt Hoffman, partner and head of talent at VC firm M13 and a former HR pro, said for a lot of people, the desire to be a part of something and help it grow is in some ways a stronger motivator than perks and pay. That\u2019s good news for startups looking for talent.<\/p>\n“I’ve always believed that people don’t join a company just for the economic benefits. They join for the opportunity to have an impact and to grow. And so in a lot of cases, it may be a more opportune time to take a chance in an early-stage company because you can focus on that long-term horizon, and you can get that opportunity to grow and have an impact,\u201d Hoffman told me.<\/p>\nFor employees, he said there will still be opportunities at good companies in any economic conditions, but attracting talent always comes down to creating a good place to work.<\/p>\n“Even in the tightest of economic environments \u2014 and we\u2019re not there yet \u2014 there\u2019s always going to be high demand for the best talent. Always. So the things that you need to do to attract, engage and retain these employees does not change,” he said.
\/>\n"extra-crunch-offer-container\"><\/div>","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"Despite the onslaught of bad news, for now, most of the sources we spoke to said folks in charge of hiring are still going to have to shake the bushes for week in TechCrunch podcasts: The new TC Pod, Chain Reaction, Found, Equity and The TechCrunch Live Podcast"},"content":{"rendered":""speakable-summary\">TechCrunch is more than just a site with words. We’re also building a growing stable of podcasts focused on the most critical topics relating to the startup and venture capital worlds. To help you find the right show for your interests, we’ve compiled our audio output from the week.<\/p>\nEmbedded below is the latest from"https:\/\/podcasts.apple.com\/us\/podcast\/chain-reaction\/id1616008890\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Chain Reaction<\/a>, our new and stellar crypto-focused podcast hosted by"https:\/\/twitter.com\/lucasmtny\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Lucas<\/a> and"https:\/\/twitter.com\/AnitaRamaswamy\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Anita<\/a>. You will also find"https:\/\/podcasts.apple.com\/us\/podcast\/found\/id1561051074\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Found<\/a>, a long-form bit of work that goes deep on the real saga of company formation from"https:\/\/twitter.com\/jordanrcrook?lang=en\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Jordan<\/a> and"https:\/\/twitter.com\/etherington\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Darrell<\/a>. There’s an audio-only version of"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/events\/techcrunchlive\/\">TechCrunch Live<\/a> hosted by"https:\/\/twitter.com\/mjburnsy\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Matt<\/a> that features founders and investors discussing successful pitch decks. Finally, there’s"https:\/\/podcasts.apple.com\/us\/podcast\/equity\/id1215439780\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Equity<\/a>, TechCrunch’s long-running, Webby-award-winning podcast focused on venture capital and the latest startup news, hosted by"http:\/\/twitter.com\/nmasc_\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Natasha<\/a>,"http:\/\/twitter.com\/bayareawriter\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Mary Ann<\/a> and"http:\/\/twitter.com\/alex\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Alex<\/a>.<\/em><\/p>\nAnd if you are more into the written over the spoken word, well"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/newsletters\">we have newsletters<\/a> on the above topics as well.<\/p>\n"gradient-text gradient-text--green-gradient\">TechCrunch Podcast<\/span><\/h2>\nEpisode 1: TechCrunch reporters Taylor Hatmaker and Kirsten Korosec join host Darrell Etherington<\/strong><\/p>\n"https:\/\/player.simplecast.com\/3cffe965-f16a-4584-b69d-87e67f0d751f?dark=false\" width=\"100%\" height=\"200px\" frameborder=\"no\" scrolling=\"no\" seamless=\"\"><\/iframe><\/p>\nWelcome to the very first episode of The TechCrunch Podcast! Every week, the new TC podcast will dive into the biggest stories in tech, as told by the writers who penned them. We’ve been developing and iterating on the concept for many months now, so we’re thrilled to finally be able to deliver our first ever full episode, which you can get by subscribing"https:\/\/podcasts.apple.com\/us\/podcast\/the-techcrunch-podcast\/id1624500693\">here on Apple Podcasts<\/a> or"https:\/\/open.spotify.com\/show\/7gaqQOeUbC6hfMkVA5fih3?si=b30642b7f1e54ea5\">Spotify<\/a>.<\/p>\nOur first ever show is typical for TechCrunch, since it was recorded mostly on the road at one of our fantastic yearly events \u2013"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/events\/tc-sessions-mobility-2022\/\">TechCrunch Mobility 2022<\/a>! If there’s one thing TC is great at, it’s rolling with the punches and improvising on the fly, and we did that with on-location and remote recording, bringing you highlights from the biggest news of the week alongside in-depth interviews with TC’s own Kirsten Korosec and Taylor Hatmaker.<\/p>\nBe sure to subscribe, and leave us a 5-star review with your feedback. We’ll be delivering the TechCrunch Podcast weekly, with fresh interviews from the writers closest to the biggest stories of the week, as well as a roundup of what you need to know for what went down in the wide world of tech.<\/p>\n\/>\n"gradient-text gradient-text--green-gradient\">Chain Reaction<\/span><\/h2>\nEpisode 6: Lightspeed\u2019s web3 guru on consumer crypto startups and the metaverse (with Mercedes Bent)<\/strong><\/p>\n"https:\/\/player.simplecast.com\/6c95a13b-acfb-478d-9707-30750d5d461f?dark=false\" width=\"100%\" height=\"200px\" frameborder=\"no\" scrolling=\"no\" seamless=\"\"><\/iframe><\/p>\nWelcome back, this week Lucas and Anita discuss the continued fallout from the broader market crash and how life is going for crypto giants on the public markets. We chat about FTX\u2019s 30-year-old billionaire CEO buying up a big chunk of Robinhood, which is pumping the gas on crypto even as the market cools. We also discuss trouble at Coinbase and the continued fallout from the collapse of Terra.<\/p>\nIn their interview this week, Lucas and Anita chat with Mercedes Bent. Bent is a venture capitalist at Lightspeed Venture Partners where she places bets on consumer products in cryptoland. Before joining Lightspeed, Bent spent some time in the VR world, so we picked her brain on where crypto fits into this metaverse future everyone is clamoring about.<\/p>\nSubscribe to the Chain Reaction newsletter to dive deeper:"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/newsletters\">https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/newsletters<\/a><\/p>\n\/>\n"gradient-text gradient-text--green-gradient\">Found<\/span><\/h2>\nEpisode 57: Justin Intal, Forage<\/strong><\/p>\n"https:\/\/player.simplecast.com\/9824a26d-62ba-4b17-9c8a-6f53fc520ee5?dark=false\" width=\"100%\" height=\"200px\" frameborder=\"no\" scrolling=\"no\" seamless=\"\"><\/iframe><\/p>\nJustin Intal from Forage joined the Found crew live. He talks about how profound struggles in her personal life motivated him to create a way for online grocers to accept EBT and SNAP benefits. He also talked about the importance of vulnerability and transparency as a CEO. Each failure is learning, so he is not about hiding his past failed companies or ideas\u2013in fact he has them written out on his Linkedin.<\/p>\n"https:\/\/docs.google.com\/forms\/d\/e\/1FAIpQLScwCotybrbEFX8yli-thpevQ4E4rLOtITXUQl6htZpoTguSiA\/viewform\">Take our listener survey<\/a>\u00a0and let us know a bit about yourself and what you think of FOUND.<\/p>\nConnect with us:<\/p>\n\nOn"https:\/\/twitter.com\/found\">\u00a0Twitter<\/a><\/li>\nOn"https:\/\/www.instagram.com\/foundpod\/\">\u00a0Instagram<\/a><\/li>\nVia email: found@techcrunch.com<\/li>\nCall us and leave a voicemail at (510) 936-1618<\/li>\n<\/ul>\n\/>\n"gradient-text gradient-text--green-gradient\">Equity<\/span><\/h2>\nEpisode 518: A Twitter Bot Wrote This\/>\n<\/strong><\/p>\n"https:\/\/player.simplecast.com\/50278df3-1442-4e8b-807d-b19bc00d82dc?dark=false\" width=\"100%\" height=\"200px\" frameborder=\"no\" scrolling=\"no\" seamless=\"\"><\/iframe><\/p>\nThe whole team was back together this week, which was pretty darn good as there was a lot to get through.\u00a0"https:\/\/twitter.com\/alex\">Alex Wilhelm,\u00a0<\/a>"https:\/\/twitter.com\/nmasc\/_\">Natasha Mascarenhas<\/a>\u00a0and\u00a0"https:\/\/twitter.com\/bayareawriter\">Mary Ann Azevedo<\/a>\u00a0were on the mic, with\u00a0"https:\/\/twitter.com\/gracedenhall\">Grace<\/a>\u00a0handling production.<\/p>\nWhat did we get into? A better question might be what did we\u00a0not\u00a0<\/i>get into:<\/p>\n\nWe started with an update from the TechCrunch Mobility event, thanks to Natasha who is on-site and\u00a0"https:\/\/twitter.com\/nmasc\/_\/status\/1527071522703101952\">up in the air.<\/a><\/li>\nFrom there it was time to talk deals, with the crew parsing\u00a0"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/17\/backed-by-forerunner-and-bezos-back-arrived-a-startup-that-lets-you-buy-into-single-family-rentals-for-as-little-as-100\/\">Arrived’s latest round<\/a>, and why\u00a0"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/16\/kolkata-chais-next-cup-includes-a-taste-of-venture-funding\/\">Kolkata Chai took some external capital,<\/a>\u00a0but very much on its own terms.<\/li>\nThen it was time to chat\u00a0"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/18\/social-maps-app-zenly-rolls-out-its-own-maps\/\">Zenly’s new mapping news<\/a>, and why startups are critical when it comes to taking on incumbents.<\/li>\nFrom there we had to ask\u00a0"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/17\/does-elon-musk-really-even-want-to-buy-twitter\/\">if Elon Musk really wants to buy Twitter<\/a>\u00a0(seemingly no?), and how tired we are about the topic itself.<\/li>\nThen we chatted through the recent unicorn\u00a0"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/17\/monday-coms-earnings-are-a-vibe-check-for-unicorns\/\">vibe check that the market got<\/a>, and the fact that most unicorns are not true IPO candidates. (Along with news from\u00a0"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/18\/square-rival-spoton-lands-300m-at-a-3-6b-valuation-after-seeing-100-arr-growth-in-2021\/\">SpotOn<\/a>, and\u00a0"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/17\/banking-as-a-service-startup-unit-closes-on-100m-at-a-1-2b-valuation\/\">Unit!)<\/a><\/li>\nAnd to close, we asked about the responsibilities of tech platforms in the wake of a number of mass shootings in the United States; where should our expectations for content moderation on platforms start, and end?<\/li>\n<\/ul>\nHugs from us to you, and we will talk to you Monday!<\/p>\nEpisode 517: Is there hope for digital health startups post-Roe?\/>\n<\/strong><\/p>\n"https:\/\/player.simplecast.com\/5387e912-17a4-46b4-a487-a8e8232569d8?dark=false\" width=\"100%\" height=\"200px\" frameborder=\"no\" scrolling=\"no\" seamless=\"\"><\/iframe><\/p>\nThis is our Wednesday show, where we niche down to a single topic, think about a question and unpack the rest. This week,\u00a0"http:\/\/twitter.com\/nmasc\/_\">Natasha<\/a>\u00a0asked:\u00a0\u00a0How do digital health startups build in a post-Roe world?<\/strong><\/p>\nThe question comes after Natasha\u2019s recent Startups Weekly column,\u00a0"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/14\/when-your-startups-core-mission-is-set-to-be-overturned\/\">“When your startup\u2019s core mission is set to be overturned.”\u00a0<\/a>The piece explores the ripple effects of the looming Roe v. Wade overturn, specifically in how it impacts startups. But, let’s not hypothesize. We brought on\u00a0"https:\/\/twitter.com\/kgfreedman?lang=en\">Kiki Freedman<\/a>, the CEO and co-founder of\u00a0"https:\/\/www.heyjane.co\/\">Hey Jane<\/a>, to answer our big questions about building, raising, and existing when so much regulatory scrutiny is weighing on your business. A direct-to-consumer health company that specializes in the delivery of abortion pills, Hey Jane about to kick off its fundraising process which makes for an interesting tension. The startup – especially today – really sits in the middle of two intense moments: an overturn to Roe v. Wade would threaten all of its work, and a toughening, risk-averse VC market could be a hurdle toward next financing.<\/p>\nEnjoy the show, and let us know if you like this interview format. Also,\u00a0"https:\/\/podcasts.apple.com\/cy\/podcast\/kiki-freedman-hey-jane\/id1561051074?i=1000539683927&l=el\">here’s the Found interview<\/a>\u00a0that we referenced during the show as well!<\/p>\nEpisode 516: What’s ahead for crypto startups?\/>\n<\/strong><\/p>\n"https:\/\/player.simplecast.com\/1a3ad63b-c945-4a9a-bfb4-7409eb95c09a?dark=false\" width=\"100%\" height=\"200px\" frameborder=\"no\" scrolling=\"no\" seamless=\"\"><\/iframe><\/p>\nHello and welcome back to\u00a0"https:\/\/open.spotify.com\/show\/5IEYLip3eDppcOmy5DmphC?si=bjgo57TCQ-uFC38-iTy6HA\">Equity<\/a>, a podcast about the business of startups, where we unpack the numbers and nuance behind the headlines. Every Monday,\u00a0"https:\/\/twitter.com\/gracedenhall\">Grace<\/a>\u00a0and\u00a0"http:\/\/twitter.com\/alex\">Alex<\/a>\u00a0scour the news and record notes on what\u2019s going on to kick off the week.<\/p>\nWhat was on our minds this morning? The following:<\/p>\n\nGlobal markets are generally down, albeit nothing too terrifying. The American stock market is trying to regain its footing after weeks of selling.<\/li>\nWhat’s ahead for crypto startups in the wake of\u00a0"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/11\/ust-founder-do-kwon-shares-plan-to-save-its-stablecoin-from-mass-destruction\/\">the Terra\/Luna meltdown<\/a>? Bloomberg\u00a0"https:\/\/www.bloomberg.com\/news\/articles\/2022-05-14\/terra-s-45-billion-face-plant-creates-a-crowd-of-crypto-losers\">wonders about a general slowdown<\/a>, and we look at\u00a0"https:\/\/www.crunchbase.com\/organization\/terra-d41a\/investor\/_financials\/funding\/_rounds\">the Crunchbase data<\/a>\u00a0of who backed the ill-fated stablecoin.<\/li>\nStartup layoffs are accelerating — not as bad as before, but enough to warrant our attention.\u00a0"https:\/\/layoffs.fyi\/\">Layoffs.FYI<\/a>\u00a0is\u00a0back,<\/i>\u00a0y’all!<\/li>\nThe\u00a0"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/16\/nigerian-freight-and-e-commerce-provider-topship-raises-2-5m-from-flexport-and-yc\/#:~:text=Link%20Copied-,Nigeria's%20Topship%20raises%20%242.5M%20from%20Flexport%20and,help%20merchants%20with%20international%20shipping&text=African%20merchants%20encounter%20many%20challenges,to%20hidden%20and%20excessive%20charges.\">Topship round<\/a>, invested in by Y Combinator and Flexport, has\u00a0"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/15\/corporate-venture-investors-pulled-back-in-q1-but-less-than-you-imagined\/\">our recent look at CVC hitting just right<\/a>.<\/li>\n<\/ul>\nIt was an awful weekend in America, which leaked into the show somewhat. Take care of one another.<\/p>\nA few housekeeping notes before we go: This is not a live-show week, so Equity will simply come out on Wednesday and Friday mornings. To help you find the right show for your interests, we’ve compiled our audio output from the week. partners","slug":"lightspeed-venture-partners","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/935716"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=935716"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=935716"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=935716"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=935716"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2322739,"date":"2022-05-21T04:00:59","date_gmt":"2022-05-21T11:00:59","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2322739"},"modified":"2022-05-20T14:21:13","modified_gmt":"2022-05-20T21:21:13","slug":"investor-advice-for-startups-2022-market-downturn","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/21\/investor-advice-for-startups-2022-market-downturn\/","title":{"rendered":"It’s not business as usual (and investors are admitting it)"},"content":{"rendered":""speakable-summary\"><\/p>\n<\/p>\n\u201cYou can often pick up significant market share in an economic downturn by just staying alive,\u201d top startup accelerator Y Combinator wrote in an internal email to its founders this week. The advice was one of 10 bullet points in a memo meant to help its companies navigate the economic"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/06\/startup-tech-layoffs-in-may\/\">downturn crushing tech<\/a>. Other standout quotes include \u201cplan for the worst\u201d and \u201cno one can predict how bad the economy will get, but things don\u2019t look good.\u201d<\/p>\nThe email is a vibe shift from"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/03\/29\/everything-you-need-to-know-about-y-combinators-winter-2022-demo-day-part-1\/\">just a few weeks ago<\/a>, when hundreds of Y Combinator startups — many of which already raised venture funding — presented themselves to the public on Demo Day. The startups were the first to receive Y Combinator\u2019s new $500,000 standard deal and were aggressively focused on international opportunity. Now, after that bonanza, YC is saying that \u201cthis slowdown will have a disproportionate impact on international companies\u201d among others.<\/p>\nY Combinator isn\u2019t the only one publishing a “black swan” memo in preparation for what\u2019s to come. TechCrunch obtained a series of memos that venture capitalist firms sent to portfolio companies about the market downturn. Some were hopeful, some were simple, and others were a vibe check as straightforward as: Can you tell us your ARR and cash burn in writing?<\/p>\nHigh efficiency > high growth<\/h2>\nReach Capital, a venture firm focused on education and access, sent a market overview to founders to help with allocating resources and priorities.<\/p>\n"extra-crunch-offer-container\"><\/div>","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"\u201cYou can often pick up significant market share in an economic downturn by just staying alive,\u201d top startup accelerator Y Combinator wrote in an internal email to its founders this week. The advice was one of 10 bullet points in a memo meant to help its companies navigate the economic downturn crushing tech. n\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=449557042"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=449557042"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=449557042"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":36665853,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/venture-2\/","name":"venture","slug":"venture-2","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/36665853"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=36665853"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=36665853"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=36665853"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=36665853"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":202,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/venture-capital\/","name":"venture capital","slug":"venture-capital","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/202"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=202"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=202"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=202"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=202"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[{"id":576796353,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/techcrunchplus\/fundraising\/","name":"Fundraising","slug":"fundraising","taxonomy":"tc_ec_category","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_ec_category\/576796353"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_ec_category"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/tc_ec_category"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tc_ec_category=576796353"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":576796356,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/techcrunchplus\/market-analysis\/","name":"Market Analysis","slug":"market-analysis","taxonomy":"tc_ec_category","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_ec_category\/576796356"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_ec_category"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/tc_ec_category"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tc_ec_category=576796356"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[]]}},{"id":2322716,"date":"2022-05-21T03:18:46","date_gmt":"2022-05-21T10:18:46","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2322716"},"modified":"2022-05-21T03:18:46","modified_gmt":"2022-05-21T10:18:46","slug":"boeings-starliner-finally-makes-it-all-the-way-to-the-iss","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/21\/boeings-starliner-finally-makes-it-all-the-way-to-the-iss\/","title":{"rendered":"Boeing’s Starliner finally makes it all the way to the ISS"},"content":{"rendered":""speakable-summary\">Boeing’s CST-100 Starliner spacecraft has had a rough couple years, but this afternoon it successfully docked with the International Space Station, its first successful mission to orbit. Despite a few hiccups, this launch went more or less as planned, and if the craft can return to Earth safely that will make this a huge accomplishment for the beleaguered aerospace company.<\/p>\nWithout recapping all the"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2019\/12\/20\/boeings-starliner-crew-capsule-fails-to-enter-planned-target-orbit-for-space-station-docking\/\">troubles<\/a> the Starliner has had, let it suffice to say that"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/08\/04\/launchpad-hiccups-indefinitely-delay-boeings-troubled-starliner-orbital-test\/\">delays<\/a> upon"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2019\/04\/03\/boeing-confirms-delay-of-starliners-first-test-flight\/\">delays<\/a> led some to question whether this capsule would ever make it to orbit, to say nothing of making regular trips with crew aboard.<\/p>\nBut naysayers may have to hold their tongues, at least for a week or two, after the Starliner’s"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/19\/watch-boeings-make-it-or-break-it-starliner-launch-today\/\">successful launch and orbital insertion yesterday<\/a>, and what appeared to be a textbook docking procedure this afternoon. Check out this great shot of the capsule during its “inbound flyaround”:<\/p>\n"embed breakout\">\n"twitter-tweet\" data-width=\"550\" data-dnt=\"true\">\n"en\" dir=\"ltr\">The"https:\/\/twitter.com\/BoeingSpace?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">@BoeingSpace<\/a>"https:\/\/twitter.com\/hashtag\/Starliner?src=hash&ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">#Starliner<\/a> fires its engines to begin its flyaround of the station for a 7:10pm ET docking today.
"https:\/\/t.co\/yuOTrZ4Jut\">https:\/\/t.co\/yuOTrZ4Jut<\/a>"https:\/\/t.co\/hKXgYU2fgQ\">pic.twitter.com\/hKXgYU2fgQ<\/a><\/p>\n— International Space Station (@Space_Station)"https:\/\/twitter.com\/Space_Station\/status\/1527760810935668736?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">May 20, 2022<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n"https:\/\/platform.twitter.com\/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"><\/script><\/div>\n<\/p>\nThat’s not to say there were no problems whatsoever. Two orbital maneuvering and attitude control (OMAC) thrusters, which are exactly as important as they sound,"https:\/\/starlinerupdates.com\/starliner-proceeding-toward-space-station\/\"> had to be shut off during the insertion burn<\/a> due to “a chamber drop in pressure.” There is also “off-nominal behavior of a thermal cooling loop.”<\/p>"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\nNaturally there are redundancies and tolerances in place for these kinds of things, and the Starliner continued on its merry way. But a multiple thruster failure isn’t something you can shrug off as “space is hard.” This was neither the first time the craft has been in space, nor its first time having thrust problems.<\/p>\nYou better believe NASA, which has paid Boeing handsomely to develop this equipment, is going to be looking at this event through an electron microscope before committing another dime to the program.<\/p>\nNevertheless, the spacecraft did complete its official orbital mission \u2014 a first for the Starliner \u2014 and a huge amount of things have to go right for that to happen. That’s definitely a win for Boeing, and they really needed one of those.<\/p>\nPlus they got this really awesome view, which looks fake but is definitely real:<\/p>\n"attachment_2322784\" style=\"width: 810px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\">"caption-attachment-2322784\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-full wp-image-2322784\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/05\/starliner-earth2.gif\" alt=\"\" width=\"800\" height=\"475\" \/>"caption-attachment-2322784\" class=\"wp-caption-text\">Image Credits:<\/strong> NASA<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"Boeing’s CST-100 Starliner spacecraft has had a rough couple years, but this afternoon it successfully docked with the International Space Station, its first successful mission to orbit. Despite a few hiccups, this launch went more or less as planned, and if the craft can return to Earth safely that will make this a huge accomplishment 322867"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/media"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/types\/attachment"}],"replies":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/comments?post=2322867"}],"author":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/tc\/v1\/users\/12084691"}]}}],"wp:term":[[{"id":576702152,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/aerospace\/","name":"Aerospace","slug":"aerospace","taxonomy":"category","parent":0,"rapidData":{"pt":"","pct":""},"submenu_categories":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/categories\/576702152"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/categories"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/category"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?categories=576702152"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?categories=576702152"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?categories=576702152"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":174,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/space\/","name":"Space","slug":"space","taxonomy":"category","parent":0,"rapidData":{"pt":"","pct":""},"submenu_categories":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/categories\/174"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/categories"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/category"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?categories=174"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?categories=174"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?categories=174"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2322890,"date":"2022-05-20T18:02:49","date_gmt":"2022-05-21T01:02:49","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2322890"},"modified":"2022-05-21T11:03:30","modified_gmt":"2022-05-21T18:03:30","slug":"pear-now-nearly-10-years-old-and-with-numerous-hits-just-closed-its-biggest-fund-by-far","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/20\/pear-now-nearly-10-years-old-and-with-numerous-hits-just-closed-its-biggest-fund-by-far\/","title":{"rendered":"Pear, now nearly 10 years old and with numerous hits, looks to close its biggest fund by far"},"content":{"rendered":""speakable-summary\">Pear, a Palo Alto, Ca.-based venture firm that we’ve been tracking since its outset in 2012, looks to be raising a fourth fund that’s targeting $410 million in capital commitments, shows a new"https:\/\/www.sec.gov\/Archives\/edgar\/data\/0001927410\/000192741022000001\/xslFormDX01\/primary_doc.xml\">SEC filing<\/a>.<\/p>\nIt would be a big step up from Pear’s first three funds, which closed progressively with $50 million in 2013, $75 million in 2016, and $160 million in capital commitments in 2019, including from a longtime limited partner, the University of Chicago.<\/p>\nReached for comment, cofounder Pejman Nozad emailed back, “I can’t comment!”<\/p>\nNozad and cofounder Mar Hershenson have long been first-stop for prominent early-stage investors that are looking to fund nascent teams, given the firm has been among the earliest backers in a notable number of companies that have gone to raise ever-bigger rounds and higher valuations, including the now publicly traded companies DoorDash and Guardant Health.<\/p>\nOther startups to attract capital from Pear before nearly any other firm was aware of their existence include the deep-linking startup Branch, which closed on"https:\/\/www.prnewswire.com\/news-releases\/branch-raises-300-million-at-4-billion-valuation-to-open-mobile-ecosystem-and-provide-solution-to-walled-gardens-301479684.html\">$300 million<\/a> in funding in February at a $4 billion valuation; Gusto, valued at $9.5 billion last summer when it raised"https:\/\/www.forbes.com\/sites\/davidjeans\/2021\/08\/10\/gusto-10-billion-ipo-hr-software\/?sh=6e04e89a6c92\">$175 million<\/a> in funding; and Aurora Solar, a firm that provides software services for the solar industry and was valued at $4 billion in February when it closed a"https:\/\/www.bloomberg.com\/news\/articles\/2022-02-28\/aurora-solar-gets-4-billion-valuation-on-backing-led-by-coatue?sref=gni836kR\">$200 million<\/a> round.<\/p>\nLike other firms, Pear is likely to see the valuations of its still-private portfolio companies slide downward — possibly by a lot — depending on how long this correction lasts.<\/p>\nHershenson, who joined TechCrunch for a mobility-focused event this week, noted on stage that startups are in for a bumpy ride, given how frothy the market had grown.<\/p>"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\nAsked if the"https:\/\/www.wsj.com\/articles\/for-tech-startups-the-party-is-over-11652710330?mod=tech_lead_pos5\">startup party is over<\/a>, Hershenson answered: “Maybe for a little while it’s over . . .The problem is that the market was priced too high in 2021, and we’re all adjusting to that price change, and that changes how companies raise money.<\/p>\n“Everybody knows that the stock market is down a lot,” she’d said. “Software stocks are down in some cases 80%. [Meanwhile] if you’re a private company, and you were very lucky and you raised money in 2021, you may have gotten a multiple of 100x on your ARR. Today, those multiples are 10x or 20x. That means that if your company was $2 billion [at the time of your fundraise], your company is [now] worth $200 million.:<\/p>\nEven with a steep reset in prices, however, Pear’s success to date is undeniable. It’s also unlikely.<\/p>\nNozad, very famously, was earlier a rug dealer who insisted on toting rugs to his clients’ homes, where during the course of long conversations, they would learn about the rug and he would learn about their business. He eventually became a scout for his boss, and a trusted friend to some very powerful people.<\/p>\n\u201cHe has a good sniffer, and I trust the guy,\u201d\u00a0 Sequoia\u2019s Doug Leone"https:\/\/www.forbes.com\/sites\/victoriabarret\/2012\/03\/21\/silicon-valleys-hottest-vc-is-a-rug-dealer\/?sh=3dfe6dbb31d5\">told Forbes<\/a> back in 2012. \u201cHe\u2019s like me, from the earth.\u201d Sequoia has, in fact, backed a number of companies that Pear has funded, including Guardant Health and DoorDash.<\/p>\nMeanwhile, his partner, Mar Hershenson, was also very much an outlier when the two struck out on their own. Despite founding several companies previously — one of which Nozad backed — and though she holds an M.S. and Ph.D. degrees in electrical engineering from Stanford University, she is a native of Spain and even more unusual in VC circles a decade ago, she is a woman who had not previously cut her teeth at someone else’s venture firm.<\/p>\nThat may not seem very notable today but in 2012, it put Hershenson in rare company.<\/p>\nAs for the team’s newest bets, Pear hosted an invite-only demo day earlier this week, coverage of which we’ll have for readers soon. (Unlike Y Combinator, the outfit holds a demo day each year for a comparatively limited number of companies — typically around 10.)<\/p>\nIn the meantime, some of its other recent checks have gone to Sudozi, a two-year-old Austin, Tex., startup that provides a SaaS platform to help enterprises improve their money management capabilities and that just this month announced a"https:\/\/venturebeat.com\/2022\/05\/12\/sudozi-nabs-4-3m-to-simplify-money-management-for-enterprises\/\">$4.3 million<\/a> seed round led by Pear.<\/p>\nPear also recently wrote a follow-on check to Osmind, a two-year-old, Bay Area-based startup that makes software to chart and update patient information and documents, with a focus on mental health. The outfit raised"https:\/\/www.fastcompany.com\/90750411\/osmind-raises-40-million-to-expand-electronic-records-for-mental-health\">$40 million<\/a> in Series B funding led by DFJ Growth, an announcement it also made earlier this month.<\/p>\nCorrection: This story originally reported that Pear’s newest fund is closed; we’ve updated the story to reflect that the fund is still being raised.<\/em><\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"Pear, a Palo Alto, Ca.-based venture firm that we’ve been tracking since its outset in 2012, looks to be raising a fourth fund that’s targeting $410 million in capital commitments, shows a new SEC filing. It would be a big step up from Pear’s first three funds, which closed progressively with $50 million in 2013, Capital","slug":"venture-capital-2","taxonomy":"category","parent":0,"rapidData":{"pt":"","pct":""},"submenu_categories":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/categories\/35394854"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/categories"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/category"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?categories=35394854"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?categories=35394854"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?categories=35394854"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2322876,"date":"2022-05-20T16:45:44","date_gmt":"2022-05-20T23:45:44","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2322876"},"modified":"2022-05-20T17:35:58","modified_gmt":"2022-05-21T00:35:58","slug":"coinbases-lost-momentum","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/20\/coinbases-lost-momentum\/","title":{"rendered":"Coinbase\u2019s lost momentum"},"content":{"rendered":""speakable-summary\">Hey everyone, and welcome back toChain Reaction.<\/strong><\/p>\nIn our"https:\/\/chain-reaction.simplecast.com\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Chain Reaction podcast<\/a> this week, Anita and I chatted with Mercedes Bent of Lightspeed Venture Partners on backing blockchain startups and the future of consumer fintech. More details below.<\/em><\/p>\nLast week, we talked about how the crypto industry needs to take a moment to reflect on buying the love of its followers. This week, we’re looking at the unhappy misfortunes of America’s favorite public crypto company<\/p>\nTo get this newsletter in your inbox every Thursday, you can subscribe on"https:\/\/link.techcrunch.com\/join\/134\/signup-all-newsletters\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">TechCrunch’s newsletter page.<\/a><\/p>\n\/>\n"attachment_2296715\" style=\"width: 690px\" class=\"wp-caption alignnone\">"caption-attachment-2296715\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-large wp-image-2296715\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/04\/GettyImages-1312540542.jpg?w=680\" alt=\"Coinbase suspends UPI payments in India days after launch\" width=\"680\" height=\"477\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/04\/GettyImages-1312540542.jpg 7200w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/04\/GettyImages-1312540542.jpg?resize=150,105 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/04\/GettyImages-1312540542.jpg?resize=300,211 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/04\/GettyImages-1312540542.jpg?resize=768,539 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/04\/GettyImages-1312540542.jpg?resize=2048,1438 2048w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/04\/GettyImages-1312540542.jpg?resize=50,35 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 680px) 100vw, 680px\" \/>"caption-attachment-2296715\" class=\"wp-caption-text\">Image Credits:<\/strong> Robert Nickelsberg \/ Getty Images<\/p><\/div><\/p>\nthe hottest take<\/h3>\nThough crypto markets have been relatively stable since last week’s bombastic dump-o-rama, gloom was on the menu this week for institutional investors and retail buyers prophesying crypto winters falling upon all ye households for the next several years.<\/p>\nThe message from VCs to crypto startups and mega corps alike was “cut the fat” — a statement which doesn’t jibe too well with the lavish launch parties and plans to quintuple hiring that plenty of founders seemed to be working toward last month. It’s been a period of unprecedented boom for crypto startups, but life has been looking a bit less pleasant for Coinbase since Bitcoin and the public markets hit their frothy peak in November of last year.<\/p>\nCoinbase is currently trading below $65 per share after a more than 80% decline from its November all-time high. A lot of other public market tech stocks are also feeling the hurt, but relative to just how much revenue Coinbase pulled in last year, it’s clear investors have nuked their expectations for the company’s future performance. Coinbase did $7.4 billion in net revenue in 2021 and is currently rocking a market cap below $14 billion. That’s nuts.<\/p>\nPublic market investors may not have the rosiest view of Coinbase, but the question is how this really impacts the company. Well, the firm is adjusting its growth expectations for one thing. COO Emilie Choi announced this week that the company was hitting the brakes, “Heading into this year, we planned to triple the size of the company. Given current market conditions, we feel it\u2019s prudent to slow hiring and reassess…”<\/p>\nThis is expected, but isn’t great for a company that has several cash-swolen competitors all chasing their market share. The company has been diversifying its offerings looking to leverage its network and provide more of a browser for the nascent web3 world, but it’s unclear what kind of consumer pickup the crypto world is looking at over the next year compared to the past couple, something which has left the company in a fairly grim position for the near-term…<\/p>\n\/>\nthe latest podcast<\/h3>\n"font-weight: 400;\">Hey, it\u2019s <\/span>"https:\/\/twitter.com\/AnitaRamaswamy\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">"font-weight: 400;\">Anita<\/span><\/a>,"font-weight: 400;\"> here to give you an update on our latest episode of Chain Reaction, where we unpack the latest web3 news, block-by-block for the crypto-curious.\u00a0<\/span><\/p>\n"font-weight: 400;\">In this episode, we talked about <\/span>"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/16\/blockchain-billionaire-sam-bankman-fried-roasts-bitcoin-popular-cryptocurrency\/\">"font-weight: 400;\">30-year-old blockchain billionaire Sam Bankman-Fried<\/span><\/a>"font-weight: 400;\"> (SBF) buying a 7.6% stake in Robinhood and what he could possibly be planning to do to help turn around the struggling exchange amid a rough first half of the year. We also explained the difference between custodial and non-custodial wallets, since Robinhood <\/span>"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/17\/robinhood-lets-users-manage-their-own-crypto-wallets-in-push-to-spur-trading\/\">"font-weight: 400;\">just announced<\/span><\/a>"font-weight: 400;\"> it\u2019s launching the latter — the latest in a spate of new products intended to attract more users to its platform.\u00a0<\/span><\/p>\n"https:\/\/player.simplecast.com\/6c95a13b-acfb-478d-9707-30750d5d461f?dark=false\" width=\"100%\" height=\"200px\" frameborder=\"no\" scrolling=\"no\" seamless=\"\"><\/iframe><\/p>\n"font-weight: 400;\">Since we talked about Robinhood, we had to go over what\u2019s up with its competitor, Coinbase, which said this week that it would be slowing its hiring plans because of the crypto market crash. We also gave listeners an update on the latest with the disgraced UST — the stablecoin that (kind of) started it all.<\/span><\/p>\n"font-weight: 400;\">Our guest this week was Mercedes Bent, an investor at Lightspeed Venture Partners who helped us unpack the loaded term that is the \u201cmetaverse\u201d and talked about some of the long-term potential she\u2019s seeing in sectors like web3 video games.\u00a0<\/span><\/p>\n"font-weight: 400;\">Subscribe to Chain Reaction on <\/span>"https:\/\/podcasts.apple.com\/us\/podcast\/chain-reaction\/id1616008890\" target=\"_blank\" in the crypto world:<\/em><\/p>\n\nCross-chain wallet"https:\/\/bitkeep.com\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">BitKeep<\/a> banks $15 million from Dragonfly<\/li>\nTreasury management target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Metatheory<\/a> banks $24 million from a16z<\/li>\nInvestment DAO"https:\/\/www.seedclub.xyz\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Seed Club<\/a> scores $15 million from Union Square Ventures, others<\/li>\nCrypto investment firm"https:\/\/elwood.io\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Elwood Technologies<\/a> gets $70 million from Goldman Sachs<\/li>\n\u00a0Web3 studio"https:\/\/www.thisisgusto.com\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Gusto Collective<\/a> nabs $11 million from Animoca<\/li>\n<\/ol>\n\/>\nTechCrunch+<\/h3>\n"c-link\" href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/12\/animoca-brands-plans-to-add-education-to-its-multibillion-dollar-nft-and-gaming-business\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\" data-stringify-link=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/12\/animoca-brands-plans-to-add-education-to-its-multibillion-dollar-nft-and-gaming-business\/\" data-sk=\"tooltip_parent\" data-remove-tab-index=\"true\">Animoca Brands plans to add education to its multibillion-dollar NFT and gaming business<\/a><\/strong><\/p>\nAnimoca Brands has grown into one of the biggest firms in the metaverse, play-to-earn gaming and NFT worlds, but its co-founder Yat Siu told TechCrunch there\u2019s a new sector the company wants to enter: education. No, not education about crypto topics, but more general educational tooling that could apply to more than one discipline. Siu said he hopes to drive the teacher economy with a \u201clearn-to-earn\u201d or \u201cteach-to-earn\u201d model, so both teachers\u2019 and students\u2019 time can be rewarded in the form of a token or cash. This push could be a new wave for the crypto ecosystem to implement additional ways to earn rewards.<\/p>\n"font-weight: 400;\">\u2014 <\/span>"https:\/\/twitter.com\/jacqmelinek\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Jacquelyn Melinek<\/a><\/p>\n\/>\nThanks for following along, and get Chain Reaction in your inbox every Thursday by subscribing on the"https:\/\/link.techcrunch.com\/join\/134\/signup-all-newsletters\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">TechCrunch newsletter page.<\/a><\/p>\n"font-weight: 400;\">\u2014\u00a0 <\/span>Lucas Matney<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"Hey everyone, and welcome back to Chain Reaction. Lucas has a degree in journalism from Northwestern University's Medill school. <\/p>\r\n\r\nThese days, Lucas is focused on coverage of the crypto\/web3 industry as well as gaming platforms and the AR\/VR space. Since 2016, Lucas has also been writing the Week in Review newsletter, which is sent to hundreds of thousands of subscribers every Saturday morning. <\/p>\r\n\r\nHe can be reached at lucas (at) techcrunch.com and followed on Twitter at @lucasmtny <\/p>\r\n\r\n<\/p>\r\n\r\nDisclosures(updated 3\/1\/22)<\/em>:<\/strong>I have investments in exchange-traded funds but do not directly trade any individual stocks myself. I own a small amount of Ethereum and USDC tokens to engage with products in the web3 ecosystem for the purpose of learning more about them. I own an ENS handle. I do not day trade any cryptocurrencies or NFTs for speculative purposes.<\/em> <\/p>","cbAvatar":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/08\/Screen-Shot-2021-08-09-at-6.58.13-PM.png","twitter":"lucasmtny","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/tc\/v1\/users\/89192944"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/tc\/v1\/users"}]}}],"wp:featuredmedia":[{"id":1713425,"date":"2018-09-16T10:30:26","slug":"techcrunch-disrupt-san-francisco-2018-day-3","type":"attachment","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2018\/09\/07\/coinbase-plots-to-become-the-new-york-stock-exchange-of-crypto-securities\/techcrunch-disrupt-san-francisco-2018-day-3\/","title":{"rendered":"TechCrunch Disrupt San Francisco 2018 – Day 3"},"author":5956050,"license":{"source_key":"flickr","person":"TechCrunch"},"authors":[5956050],"caption":{"rendered":"SAN FRANCISCO, CA – SEPTEMBER 07: Coinbase Co-founder and CEO Brian Armstrong (L) and moderator Fitz Tepper speak onstage during Day 3 of TechCrunch Disrupt SF 2018 at Moscone Center on September 7, 2018 in San Francisco, California. Tepper<\/p>\n"},"alt_text":"","media_type":"image","mime_type":"image\/jpeg","media_details":{"width":4066,"height":2706,"file":"2018\/09\/coinbase-disrupt-brian-armstrong-1.jpg","sizes":{"thumbnail":{"file":"coinbase-disrupt-brian-armstrong-1.jpg?resize=150,100","width":150,"height":100,"filesize":1695006,"mime_type":"image\/jpeg","source_url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/09\/coinbase-disrupt-brian-armstrong-1.jpg?w=150"},"medium":{"file":"coinbase-disrupt-brian-armstrong-1.jpg?resize=300,200","width":300,"height":200,"filesize":1695006,"mime_type":"image\/jpeg","source_url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/09\/coinbase-disrupt-brian-armstrong-1.jpg?w=300"},"medium_large":{"file":"coinbase-disrupt-brian-armstrong-1.jpg?resize=768,511","width":768,"height":511,"filesize":1695006,"mime_type":"image\/jpeg","source_url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/09\/coinbase-disrupt-brian-armstrong-1.jpg?w=1024"},"large":{"file":"coinbase-disrupt-brian-armstrong-1.jpg?resize=680,453","width":680,"height":453,"filesize":1695006,"mime_type":"image\/jpeg","source_url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/09\/coinbase-disrupt-brian-armstrong-1.jpg?w=680"},"1536x1536":{"file":"coinbase-disrupt-brian-armstrong-1.jpg?resize=1536,1022","width":1536,"height":1022,"filesize":1695006,"mime_type":"image\/jpeg","source_url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/09\/coinbase-disrupt-brian-armstrong-1.jpg?w=1536"},"2048x2048":{"file":"coinbase-disrupt-brian-armstrong-1.jpg?resize=2048,1363","width":2048,"height":1363,"filesize":1695006,"mime_type":"image\/jpeg","source_url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/09\/coinbase-disrupt-brian-armstrong-1.jpg?w=2048"},"guest-author-32":{"file":"coinbase-disrupt-brian-armstrong-1.jpg?resize=32,32","width":32,"height":32,"filesize":1695006,"mime_type":"image\/jpeg","source_url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/09\/co
