Reaction","slug":"chain-reaction","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/576991668"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=576991668"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=576991668"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=576991668"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=576991668"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":98743001,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/coinbase\/","name":"coinbase","slug":"coinbase","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/98743001"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=98743001"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=98743001"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=98743001"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=98743001"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":576596953,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/cryptocurrencies\/","name":"cryptocurrencies","slug":"cryptocurrencies","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/576596953"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=576596953"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=576596953"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=576596953"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=576596953"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":284712,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/decentralization\/","name":"decentralization","slug":"decentralization","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/284712"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=284712"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=284712"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=284712"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=284712"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":576603310,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/emilie-choi\/","name":"Emilie choi","slug":"emilie-choi","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/576603310"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=576603310"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=576603310"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=576603310"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=576603310"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":577017817,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/encode-club\/","name":"Encode Club","slug":"encode-club","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/577017817"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=577017817"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=577017817"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=577017817"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=577017817"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2322679,"date":"2022-05-20T16:29:49","date_gmt":"2022-05-20T23:29:49","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2322679"},"modified":"2022-05-21T10:58:17","modified_gmt":"2022-05-21T17:58:17","slug":"why-founders-should-start-talking-now-to-bankers-and-potential-buyers","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/20\/why-founders-should-start-talking-now-to-bankers-and-potential-buyers\/","title":{"rendered":"Why founders should start talking now to bankers and potential buyers"},"content":{"rendered":""speakable-summary\">Founders have gotten the memo that the ground is shifting under their feet right now. What to do about it is the question. Already, teams are making plans to scale back their spending to preserve capital. They’re making painful staff cuts toward that same end — or else instituting hiring freezes.<\/p>\nBut they should also be thinking a lot harder about building relationships with bankers and the larger companies that might conceivably be interested in acquiring their startup, say two attorneys who work on both the ‘buy’ and ‘sell’ side of transactions, with both large companies and venture-backed outfits, and who both have more than 20 years of experience.<\/p>\nIndeed, to better understand some of the options founders may have, we talked earlier today with Denny Kwon and Scott Anthony, both of whom represent the white shoe law firm Covington & Burling (where former U.S. Attorney General Eric Holder is also an attorney). They answered a range of questions that we thought startups might be wondering about right now. Our chat has been edited lightly for length.<\/p>\nTC: How much has the world changed in the last few weeks?<\/strong><\/p>\nDK: There is certainly a feeling of more pressure on sellers to get deals done as quickly as possible in light of the fact that there\u2019s a lot of market volatility right now and they don\u2019t know how buyers may be reacting to a significant decline in their stock price. Smaller companies are also facing the prospect of a slightly more challenging fundraising market, so alternatives for them are narrowing.<\/p>\nTC: Given that public shares are so volatile right now, are acquirers more or less inclined to offer equity as a component of a deal?\u00a0<\/strong><\/p>\nDK: It’s much more challenging to price deals with a significant stock component in this market. With any volatility, you don\u2019t get a clear sense of the inherent value of a share, so all-cash deals are much more favorable to targets.<\/p>"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\nTC: Are targets in a position right now to make demands? How much leverage does a startup with dwindling options really have?<\/strong><\/p>\nDK: Whenever we see volatile markets, where valuations were incredibly high [and are] being reset, it always takes time for sellers’ expectations to reset as well, so although they may be a temporary [lull in activity] because of the market, if there\u2019s a ‘normalization’ that\u2019s to come, we\u2019ll probably see M&A activity, especially where valuation expectations are reduced on both the buyers’ and the sellers’ side.<\/p>\nMy sense [right now] is that buyers may view the market correction as being potentially opportunistic but sellers may not have the same expectations because they may hope for a rebound in the near future. Once seller expectations come down and they continue to hear from VCs that funding may not be as available as it was 6 to 12 months ago, they\u2019ll be even harder pressed to turn away acquisition offers that come in.<\/p>\nTC: Are you seeing deals being yanked as buyers look to reprice earlier agreements to their benefit?<\/strong><\/p>\nDK: The pending deals I\u2019m working on are continuing apace.<\/p>\nTC: We’re all hearing — and reading — about very steep valuation drops already. Do you have any sense of how much value your clients have lost in recent weeks or whether certain sectors are getting hit harder than others?<\/strong><\/p>\nSA:There’s valuation pressure, but it’s hard to gauge [the degree]. Certainly, we have companies that were racing to close valuations [before Russia invaded Ukraine] and [that period since] has changed everyone\u2019s expectations. I think there’s concern on the company side that investors are sitting out and that\u2019s driving valuations down.<\/p>\nCompanies with revenues and good prospects will weather any downturn better — they always have. Sector wise, it will depend, but the whole stablecoin [debacle] hasn\u2019t helped the crypto stuff.<\/p>\nTC: How big a concern are antitrust regulators to your bigger clients?\u00a0<\/strong><\/p>\nDK: It’s top of mind for all practitioners, but there’s a dichotomy in that some transactions are reportable and others are not. For those that are reportable — the threshold is approximately $100 million —\u00a0 we\u2019re spending an incredible amount of time analyzing the potential for regulatory issues.<\/p>\nTC: How long does an M&A process take, and at what point do both sides agree on a price?<\/strong><\/p>\nDK: From that initial approach from an acquirer, the time period can vary from a few weeks if there is alignment right away, up to several months if the target company wants to see if there is other interest. A lot depends on how compelling that first offer may appear. Once you get to a handshake on a valuation, it\u2019s usually a six- to eight-week process to get a signed definitive agreement.<\/p>\nSA: If the [startup] is the one that is making the decision to find a buyer, then the process \u2013 maybe they hire bankers, maybe they use board members\u2019 connections to reach out to strategics \u2013 the process and timing can be very different depending on how quickly they need the money and how quickly they can get potential buyers interested . . . and the size of the company, but buyers are still going to run their diligence process.<\/p>\nTC: Let’s assume M&A will be a more significant factor, given the cooling funding environment. If you were to advise a startup on the pros and cons about proceeding, what points would you make?<\/strong><\/p>\nDK: Many companies at an inflection point that need to raise money to fund their growth or expansion are going to have a difficult decision to make, which is to either raise a new round where the valuation may not meet their expectations or [where they see a lot of dilution], or an M&A exit, where they see proceeds now but lose out on [potential] upside.<\/p>\nTC: Should startups that are open to selling be reaching out to anyone, or should they wait to see who approaches them? Some might worry their startup’s value will drop as soon as they indicate a willingness to sell.<\/strong><\/p>\nDK:\u00a0 I’d be advising startups to talk to bankers and keep relationships up with people at the larger companies they know simply because we may be in for a longer-term correction, where funding becomes even more challenging than it has been over the last couple of months.<\/p>\nSA: Having relationships with the bankers is prudent so if you have to check the market, you have those relationships already. Also, keeping in contact with customers and bigger strategic partners that would be natural buyers for the company could short-circuit any kind of sale process later.<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"Founders have gotten the memo that the ground is shifting under their feet right now. What to do about it is the question. Already, teams are making plans to scale back their spending to preserve capital. They’re making painful staff cuts toward that same end — or else instituting hiring freezes. But they should also […]<\/p>\n","protected":false},"author":89646803,"featured_media":2176025,"comment_status":"open","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"template":"","format":"standard","meta":{"outcome":"","status":"","crunchbase_tag":0,"amp_status":"","relegenceEntities":[],"relegenceSubjects":[],"carmot_uuid":"9da94d52-a7c1-3b85-862b-1423abebec99","jetpack_publicize_message":"","jetpack_is_tweetstorm":false,"jetpack_publicize_feature_enabled":true},"categories":[20429,17396],"tags":[821440,18960,449557042,202],"crunchbase_tag":[],"tc_stories_tax":[],"tc_ec_category":[],"tc_event":[],"jetpack_featured_media_url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/07\/GettyImages-1251416624.jpg","parsely":{"version":"1.0.0","meta":{"@context":"http:\/\/schema.org","@type":"WebPage","headline":"YC's capital","slug":"venture-capital","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/202"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=202"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=202"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=202"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=202"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2322705,"date":"2022-05-20T15:15:31","date_gmt":"2022-05-20T22:15:31","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2322705"},"modified":"2022-05-20T14:00:10","modified_gmt":"2022-05-20T21:00:10","slug":"daily-crunch-south-koreas-special-financial-crimes-unit-is-investigating-do-kwon","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/20\/daily-crunch-south-koreas-special-financial-crimes-unit-is-investigating-do-kwon\/","title":{"rendered":"Daily Crunch: South Korea\u2019s special financial crimes unit is investigating Do Kwon"},"content":{"rendered":""speakable-summary\">What is that we hear? Is that the Friday, May 20, 2022, on the calendar and the soft, alluring siren\u2019s song of a weekend that\u2019s right around the corner? Why, yes, that must be it!<\/p>\nOur events team is busy putting together an awesome TechCrunch Disrupt, and we are psyched about Startup Battlefield, where the winner will walk away with a $100,000 check to continue building the future it is envisioning.
"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/20\/how-to-earn-a-shot-at-100000-in-equity-free-funding-at-techcrunch-disrupt\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Here\u2019s how to be in the running<\/a>. \u2014"http:\/\/twitter.com\/haje\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Haje<\/a> and"https:\/\/twitter.com\/ChristineMHall\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Christine<\/a><\/p>\nThe TechCrunch Top 3<\/h2>\n\n"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/20\/terra-creator-do-kwon-faces-prosecutions-in-south-korea\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">UST UGH<\/strong><\/a>: Terraform Labs founder Do Kwon has some \u2019splaining to do with South Korea\u2019s special financial crimes unit, which has launched an investigation into the collapse of Terraform\u2019s stablecoin TerraUSD (UST) and its sister token Luna earlier this month. Prosecutors might be first in line, but the line is growing, with investors filing a lawsuit against Kwon and his co-founder Daniel Shin over alleged charges of fraud and other financial regulation violations. Also joining are Luna Foundation Guard advisors who tell"https:\/\/twitter.com\/jacqmelinek\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Jacquie<\/a> that they have not heard from Kwon in weeks.<\/li>\n"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/20\/costa-rica-ransomware-attack\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Standoff<\/strong><\/a>: We enjoyed reading"https:\/\/twitter.com\/carlypage_\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Carly<\/a>\u2019s piece outlining what happened with Costa Rica\u2019s ransomware attacks \u2014 the Conti gang is attempting to overthrow the government \u2014 and who could be next. As of our newsletter time, the ransom part was still going on. The deadline given was May 23.<\/li>\n"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/20\/as-klarna-looks-to-raise-more-capital-is-it-cutting-its-valuation-enough\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Klarna konundrum<\/strong><\/a>: The payments company is reportedly the latest to be fine with lowering its valuation, and in its case, there is some capital attached. We think"https:\/\/twitter.com\/alex\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Alex<\/a> sums it up well saying, \u201cNo one likes a down round. They are dilutive, messy and demoralizing. But they are also miles better than not raising money and dying, so companies raise them when required.\u201d He goes into why Klarna taking an insider round with a cut valuation is worth it or not.<\/li>\n<\/ul>\nStartups and VC<\/h2>\nToday, we got a wee bit excited about Haje\u2019s somewhat-expletive-filled rant about"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/20\/coca-cola-bottle-cap\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Coca-Cola\u2019s new bottle caps that don\u2019t detach from the bottle, against a backdrop of greenwashing<\/a>.<\/p>\nWe also loved"https:\/\/twitter.com\/bheater\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Brian<\/a>\u2019s piece about Pebble founder Eric Migicovsky\u2019s love for small phones. \u201c"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/20\/one-mans-quest-to-bring-back-the-small-phone\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">If no one else makes one I guess I will be forced to make it myself,<\/a>\u201d Migicovsky laments.<\/p>\nAlso,"https:\/\/twitter.com\/bheater\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Brian<\/a> and"https:\/\/twitter.com\/haje\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Haje<\/a> tag-teamed on a pair of articles about Sony\u2019s new earbuds. Brian"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/18\/sony-delivers-a-killer-new-pair-of-earbuds\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">covers the buds themselves<\/a> (\u201cAs someone who tests a lot of earbuds over the course of a year, the LinkBuds S are among the best sounding and most comfortable I\u2019ve had in my ears\u201d), and Haje double-clicked on"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/20\/endel-sony-partnership\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">the Endel soundscape-creating app<\/a>.<\/p>\nStrap on your dancing shoes, there\u2019s a veritable dance party of more news coming your way:<\/p>\n\nNot half baked<\/strong>: Galley Solutions, a food data company providing food operators with technology to"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/20\/galley-solutions-turns-kitchen-chaos-into-recipe-for-streamlined-operations\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">make more profitable decisions around their culinary operations<\/a>, raised $14.2 million in Series A funding,"https:\/\/twitter.com\/christinemhall\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Christine <\/a>reports.<\/li>\nCovid has us feline fine<\/strong>: Tell you who isn\u2019t upset by COVID:"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/20\/covid-was-the-best-thing-for-kitty-as-insurance-apps-for-pets-boom\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">The litany of apps offering pet insurance<\/a>.
"https:\/\/twitter.com\/mikebutcher\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Mike<\/a> reports that \u201cSome seven in 10 pet parents take their pet\u2019s physical and mental health more seriously than their own.\u201d<\/li>\nTaking stock of what\u2019s next<\/strong>: Not happy with just trading crypto,"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/19\/crypto-exchange-ftx-expands-into-stock-trading-retail-investors\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">FTX launches a stock-trading feature<\/a> as well,"https:\/\/twitter.com\/anitaramaswamy\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Anita<\/a> reports.<\/li>\nPumping the brakes<\/strong>:"https:\/\/twitter.com\/bheater\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Brian<\/a> has the behind-the-scenes on"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/19\/the-lowdown-on-the-slowdown\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">what\u2019s going on with the startup slowdown<\/a>.<\/li>\nGetting ships in shipshape<\/strong>: Shipping is dirty business, and"https:\/\/twitter.com\/harrisonweber\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Harri<\/a> reports on investors<\/li>\n34% women (female investors or female-headed funds)<\/li>\n26% venture capitalists<\/li>\n23% family and friends<\/li>\n18% international investors<\/li>\n15% angel groups<\/li>\n<\/ul>\n\u201cWhen building an investor funnel, vocalizing what you want is crucial to finding the right investors,\u201d says Papin-Zoghbi.<\/p>\n\u201cFinding the right investors is /\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/05\/GettyImages-953920768.jpg?w=50&h=50&crop=1"},"guest-author-64":{"file":"GettyImages-953920768.jpg?resize=64,64","width":64,"height":64,"filesize":16562026,"mime_type":"image\/jpeg","source_url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/05\/GettyImages-953920768.jpg?w=64&h=64&crop=1"},"guest-author-96":{"file":"GettyImages-953920768.jpg?resize=96,96","width":96,"height":96,"filesize":16562026,"mime_type":"image\/jpeg","source_url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/05\/GettyImages-953920768.jpg?w=96&h=96&crop=1"},"guest-author-128":{"file":"GettyImages-953920768.jpg?resize=128,128","width":128,"height":128,"filesize":16562026,"mime_type":"image\/jpeg","source_url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/05\/GettyImages-953920768.jpg?w=128&h=128&crop=1"},"concierge-thumb":{"file":"GettyImages-953920768.jpg?resize=50,28","width":50,"height":28,"filesize":16562026,"mime_type":"image\/jpeg","source_url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/05\/GettyImages-953920768.jpg?w=50"},"full":{"file":"GettyImages-953920768.jpg","width":1024,"height":576,"mime_type":"image\/jpeg","source_url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/05\/GettyImages-953920768.jpg"}},"image_meta":{"aperture":"0","credit":"Getty Block chain network Concept","orientation":"0","keywords":[]},"filesize":16562026},"source_url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/05\/GettyImages-953920768.jpg","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/media\/1994308"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/media"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/types\/attachment"}],"replies":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/comments?post=1994308"}],"author":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/tc\/v1\/users\/133574210"}]}}],"wp:term":[[{"id":17396,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tc\/","name":"TC","slug":"tc","taxonomy":"category","parent":0,"rapidData":{"pt":"","pct":""},"submenu_categories":[],"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/categories\/17396"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/categories"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/category"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?categories=17396"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?categories=17396"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?categories=17396"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[{"id":577019184,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/aoa-dx\/","name":"AOA Dx","slug":"aoa-dx","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/577019184"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=577019184"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=577019184"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=577019184"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=577019184"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":961220,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/daily-crunch\/","name":"Daily Crunch","slug":"daily-crunch","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/961220"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=961220"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=961220"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=961220"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=961220"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":577015875,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/do-kwon\/","name":"Do Kwon","slug":"do-kwon","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/577015875"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=577015875"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=577015875"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=577015875"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=577015875"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":80687524,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/snapchat\/","name":"Snapchat","slug":"snapchat","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/80687524"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=80687524"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=80687524"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=80687524"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=80687524"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":449557042,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/startups\/","name":"Startups","slug":"startups","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/449557042"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=449557042"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=449557042"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=449557042"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=449557042"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":576901140,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/terraform-labs\/","name":"Terraform Labs","slug":"terraform-labs","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/576901140"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=576901140"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=576901140"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=576901140"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=576901140"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":202,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/venture-capital\/","name":"venture capital","slug":"venture-capital","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/202"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=202"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=202"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=202"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=202"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2322692,"date":"2022-05-20T14:57:25","date_gmt":"2022-05-20T21:57:25","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2322692"},"modified":"2022-05-20T14:57:36","modified_gmt":"2022-05-20T21:57:36","slug":"amazon-astro","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/20\/amazon-astro\/","title":{"rendered":"Even Amazon can’t quite figure out what Astro is for"},"content":{"rendered":""speakable-summary\">"featured__span-first-words\">Amazon’s cute little<\/span>"https:\/\/www.amazon.com\/dp\/B078NSDFSB\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Astro<\/a> robot has been scurrying its way around my apartment for the past few weeks. It has no arms to scratch its own head in confusion, but I am willing to do that for him. As part of Amazon’s Day 1 Editions program, the robot is a $1,000 invitation-only program with limited numbers of robots available, as the company is trying to get them into consumers’ hands with a question: How would you use this?<\/p>\nThe company suggests that some use cases include home monitoring — an autonomous home-security system that can wander around from room to room. Astro has the ability to patrol a home with Ring Protect Pro, pop its periscope camera to see the counters, detect unidentified people when in \u201caway mode,\u201d send alerts when it hears sounds like glass breaking and more. You can also use it when you\u2019re home \u2014 if you hear the dog barking at night, you can send Astro to see what\u2019s happening without having to leave the cozy cocoon of your duvet-burrito.<\/p>\nThe company also suggests that Astro might be a good solution for offering remote care.\u00a0Your loved one can ask Astro to set and deliver reminders, or you can useDrop In<\/em> to stay connected. Plus, Astro works with Alexa Together, which allows for remote care for aging loved ones, or for offering care for people who have mobility challenges or other disabilities.<\/p>\nAmazon also offers companionship as a potential use case — it suggests all the fun things Astro can do (things like \u201cAstro beatbox,\u201d or \u201cwhat\u2019s your favorite animal?\u201d are top items, the company suggests), and it has other features that make it seem more like a pet than a Skynet-harboring robot of death and destruction.<\/p>\nThe whole purpose of a Day 1 Edition product is for Amazon’s product teams to get their most ambitious projects into customers\u2019 hands faster so they can provide feedback that, in this case, will help shape the Astro experience. It makes sense. Right now, Astro is a robust system and can handle a wide array of commands and tasks that customers are finding useful. The robot has a little carrying tray and a USB port for extensions that will give it any number of interesting new powers, extendable by hackers and tech-savvy users, much in the same way that someone can write and deploy an Alexa skill today.<\/p>\n"attachment_2322758\" style=\"width: 1034px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\">"caption-attachment-2322758\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"breakout size-full wp-image-2322758\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/05\/PXL_20220520_210408573.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1024\" height=\"682\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/05\/PXL_20220520_210408573.jpg 2024w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/05\/PXL_20220520_210408573.jpg?resize=150,100 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/05\/PXL_20220520_210408573.jpg?resize=300,200 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/05\/PXL_20220520_210408573.jpg?resize=768,512 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/05\/PXL_20220520_210408573.jpg?resize=680,453 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/05\/PXL_20220520_210408573.jpg?resize=1536,1024 1536w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/05\/PXL_20220520_210408573.jpg?resize=50,33 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px\" \/>"caption-attachment-2322758\" class=\"wp-caption-text\">Astro’s sensors mean it doesn’t bump into things too often. And the paint along the bottom of the chassis, and the scrapes on the walls of my apartment, indicate that Astro still has a little bit of learning to do on that front.
Image Credits:<\/strong>"http:\/\/kamps.org\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Haje Kamps<\/a> for TechCrunch<\/p><\/div><\/p>\nPersonally, throughout my time with Astro, I thought the robot was adorable. The speakers are good, and it’s kinda fun to have a boombox trail around and play your tunes or podcasts as you are doing chores. As a piece of first-generation tech, it’s an impressive feat that has tremendous potential. But that alone isn’t enough to make a product. In a world where the environment is front of mind, we could do with fewer gadgets that will end up in landfills eventually, not more, and so I find myself wondering what this thing is for. I can imagine a number of niche use cases — including the ones listed above — but I keep being unclear on whether this is a device that needs to exist at all.<\/p>"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\nI spoke with Anthony Robson, the principal product manager for robotic technologies and consumer robotics at Amazon, to try to get to the bottom of things. It quickly became clear that Astro’s ambition is sky-high, and that the Amazon team doesn’t quite know which direction that ambition will take it. By design, it claims, which I have some respect for, but it seems weird to me to take a “let’s build it and see if they will come, and what they will use it for” approach.<\/p>\nDon’t misunderstand me; I do believe there are places and use cases where Amazon’s adorable little robot friend makes a lot of sense — but when I talk to startups day in and day out, it feels really jarring. I wouldn’t let a startup get away with a solution looking for a problem, and so it feels curious to be tempted to let Amazon — who really should know better — off the hook.<\/p>\n“This is the very first robot in a brand new category of robots. When we started this program, we were like, why not us? Why not Amazon? You know, we have this great ecosystem with Alex and the AI chops to be able to do this. Let’s do it, let’s learn from customers,” comments Robson. “We went out and did a lot of research around what kinds of things people could envision robots helping them in their home. The home monitoring capabilities were certainly the most popular thing people could envision. I’d love to be able to check if I left the stove on, or whether my back door is unlocked. I’d love to be able to check if I need to buy bananas because the fruit bowl is empty. I want to be able to check if the kids came home or to be notified when they come home. I want to be able to talk to them and find them in the house. So that was a very popular use case that people identified. There are a number of use cases.”<\/p>\n"attachment_2322765\" style=\"width: 1034px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\">"caption-attachment-2322765\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"breakout size-full wp-image-2322765\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/05\/PXL_20220520_210401662.jpg\" alt=\"Astro Cargo Bay\" width=\"1024\" height=\"683\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/05\/PXL_20220520_210401662.jpg 1462w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/05\/PXL_20220520_210401662.jpg?resize=150,100 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/05\/PXL_20220520_210401662.jpg?resize=300,200 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/05\/PXL_20220520_210401662.jpg?resize=768,512 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/05\/PXL_20220520_210401662.jpg?resize=680,453 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/05\/PXL_20220520_210401662.jpg?resize=50,33 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px\" \/>"caption-attachment-2322765\" class=\"wp-caption-text\">Astro’s cargo bay is sizeable and has a USB-C port to extend its functionality further. An SDK to build software for Astro is in the works, Amazon suggests.
Image Credits:<\/strong>\u00a0"http:\/\/kamps.org\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Haje Kamps<\/a> for TechCrunch<\/p><\/div><\/p>\nThe ideas came fast and thick, and every time I found myself wondering; yes, but… Really? Would customers potentially pay $1,000 to solve this problem?<\/p>\nOf course, the additional flexibility of the Astro platform broadens the potential quite a bit.<\/p>\n“We insisted on having some level of extensibility. We’re gonna learn so much about every home — and every home is going to be different and have different needs. So we added a cargo bay area with a USB port, and asked the question ‘how can we extend this platform to do more things for more people?’ We didn’t envision at the beginning of this program that we would have a pet food dispenser at the launch event,” marvels Robson. “We have customers who are working in their home offices on either side of the house sending things to each other using their Astro. We are learning, we are listening and we are adapting. We’re going to extend Astro’s capabilities as we learn from customers.”<\/p>\nThe product team does have a few things on its wish list that it wasn’t able to prioritize for launch for various reasons.<\/p>\n“There are a lot of things that, simply from a practical perspective, we couldn’t add. Astro doesn’t climb stairs, for example. The level of complexity that would add to the product would simply make it too costly, and make it so it’s not accessible to as many people as we would like,” explains Robson. “We had to make trade-offs like that. We would have liked the periscope camera to go that little bit higher. But we had to compromise and say, you know, this is just enough to see over the counters. That is perfect — that keeps the device small.”<\/p>\nThe product team also suggests that it wanted Astro to be able to move around much faster. At its current pace, you can out-walk it if you stroll briskly through the hallways of your mansion — but speed also equals trade-offs. The laws of physics start getting in the way pretty quickly, in other words.<\/p>\n“A"font-size: 1rem; letter-spacing: -0.1px;\">gain, the complexity of being able to make sure that it can be safe at all times goes up exponentially. A factor of two, with every increase in speed,” explains Robson. “You have to be very judicious about how much speed you put in because it’s going to make your sensing and your safety solutions twice or multiple times more complex.”<\/span><\/p>\nThe Astro team hasn’t launched a developer toolkit for the Astro robot yet, but that’s on its way, too.<\/p>\n“We’re working hard with strategic partners. I think [an Astro SDK] is going to be happening. We want to bring that intelligent motion capability to more and more skills and accessories in the future,” says Robson. “It is not something we have ready today, but it’s coming very soon. We’re working on it as hard as we can.”<\/p>\n"attachment_2322768\" style=\"width: 1034px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\">"caption-attachment-2322768\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"breakout size-full wp-image-2322768\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/05\/PXL_20220520_210145989.jpg\" alt=\"Amazon Astro with periscope camera\" width=\"1024\" height=\"1024\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/05\/PXL_20220520_210145989.jpg 1958w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/05\/PXL_20220520_210145989.jpg?resize=150,150 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/05\/PXL_20220520_210145989.jpg?resize=300,300 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/05\/PXL_20220520_210145989.jpg?resize=768,768 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/05\/PXL_20220520_210145989.jpg?resize=680,680 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/05\/PXL_20220520_210145989.jpg?resize=1536,1536 1536w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/05\/PXL_20220520_210145989.jpg?resize=32,32 32w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/05\/PXL_20220520_210145989.jpg?resize=50,50 50w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/05\/PXL_20220520_210145989.jpg?resize=64,64 64w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/05\/PXL_20220520_210145989.jpg?resize=96,96 96w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/05\/PXL_20220520_210145989.jpg?resize=128,128 128w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px\" \/>"caption-attachment-2322768\" class=\"wp-caption-text\">The periscope camera pops out and extends telescopically, enabling Astro to look over obstacles and on countertops. A very elegant design choice.
Image Credits:<\/strong>"http:\/\/kamps.org\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Haje Kamps<\/a> for TechCrunch<\/p><\/div><\/p>\nThe comms team for Astro is excited about the potential of the robot as a comms and monitoring tool. It tells the story of one customer; their father-in-law had fallen out of his wheelchair. The family used Astro to communicate and coordinate emergency service responses to help him get back up. Giving additional, roaming assistance to people living independently seems like a powerful use case — except for the quirk of Astro not being able to climb stairs or open doors.<\/p>\nI did have a couple of fun interactions with Astro that surprised and delighted me. For example, as one part of the setup process, Astro tells you to take a couple of steps back to make space for it to leave its charging dock. As it did that, I swear it flicked the screen representing its “face”, much like one would wave one’s hands to shoo someone away. I was never able to get Astro to do it again, and the product team wasn’t able to confirm whether I hallucinated that, or whether that’s something Astro actually does.<\/p>\n“You know, that’s the thing when you give a robot a body language, depending on what it has to do, it’s going to move in the way it needs to move. Sometimes those things end up being interesting combinations,” laughed Robson. “So I can’t think of exactly why that would happen, but… I have been surprised by Astro before.”<\/p>\nAstro is an extraordinarily well-thought-out robot on a technical level. The big wheels mean it can climb over thresholds between rooms with no issues. It got stuck on my bath mat a few times but managed to dislodge itself every time, which is impressive. When I was testing Astro, I also had a foster kitten, and Astro and Chairman Meow seemed to become good friends, with the two of them chasing each other around the apartment. Astro ran over Meow’s tail once, and Meow got his revenge by folding over the bath mat, trapping Astro in the bathroom for a few hours. I’m not convinced Meow did that on purpose, to be fair, but it did strike me as funny.<\/p>\nThe periscope camera is an extraordinarily clever feature that dramatically increases the usefulness of Astra, and the wayfinding tech is impressive. Telling Astro to go to the kitchen, and having it dutifully scurrying its way around my stacks of Amazon deliveries, office chairs and the odd shoe strewn along the flow was entertaining. A lot of work went into making Astro seem non-threatening. It moves slowly and gingerly near people and pets, it doesn’t bump into stuff all that much, and when it does, it does so carefully. The screen and Astro’s “face” are expressive, and cute, and invite a high degree of trust and user-friendliness. It shows that Amazon has the capacity of building incredibly capable robotics, even when it is compromising on product issues along the way.<\/p>\nIt’s been fun to have Astro wandering about my apartment for a few days, and most of the time I seemed to use it as a roving boom box that also has Alexa capabilities. That’s cute, and all, but $1,000 would buy Alexa devices for every thinkable surface in my room and leave me with enough cash left over to cover the house in cameras. I simply continue to struggle with why Astro makes sense. But then, that’s true for any product that is trying to carve out a brand new product category.<\/p>\nI won’t miss it when I return it to its corporate office to be passed on to the next journalist who will be taking a closer look, which is rarely a good sign, but I hope that Amazon learns enough so it becomes better at telling the story of its adorable little robot. It is, truly, a solution that is carefully and adorably scurrying around looking for a use case. If Astro’s persistence is any indication, it will eventually find one.<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"Amazon’s cute little Astro robot has been scurrying its way around my apartment for the past few weeks. It has no arms to scratch its own head in confusion, but I am willing to do that for him. As part of Amazon’s Day 1 Editions program, the robot is a $1,000 invitation-only program with limited robot","slug":"home-robot","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/449558673"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=449558673"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=449558673"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=449558673"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=449558673"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":90436,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/robot\/","name":"robot","slug":"robot","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/90436"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=90436"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=90436"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=90436"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=90436"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":13426,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/robotics\/","name":"robotics","slug":"robotics","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/13426"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=13426"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=13426"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=13426"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=13426"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2313292,"date":"2022-05-20T14:45:40","date_gmt":"2022-05-20T21:45:40","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2313292"},"modified":"2022-05-20T14:50:50","modified_gmt":"2022-05-20T21:50:50","slug":"mobility-marketplaces-and-brake-repair-on-techcrunch-live","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/20\/mobility-marketplaces-and-brake-repair-on-techcrunch-live\/","title":{"rendered":"Mobility marketplaces and brake repair on TechCrunch Live"},"content":{"rendered":""speakable-summary\">Walker Drewett founded NuBrakes in May 2019. According to Mike Ghaffary, GP at Canvas Ventures, Drewett is building a high-growth business powered by a marketplace model, which is why Ghaffary led the company’s Series A. The product is simple: On-demand vehicle brake repair services. Join this episode to hear how Drewett raised capital and built NuBrakes on the learnings from his previous startup, NuWash (it’s on-demand car washes, of course).<\/p>\nThis event opens on"https:\/\/hopin.com\/events\/techcrunch-live-with-canvas-ventures-and-nubrakes?utm_source=tc&utm_campaign=post\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">May 25 at 11:30 a.m. PDT\/2:30 p.m. EDT<\/a> with networking and pitch practice submissions. live announcement","slug":"techcrunch-live-announcement","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/576928563"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=576928563"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=576928563"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=576928563"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=576928563"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":34926503,"link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/transportation-2\/","name":"transportation","slug":"transportation-2","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/34926503"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=34926503"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/battlefield-companies?tags=34926503"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=34926503"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=34926503"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2322738,"date":"2022-05-20T14:31:03","date_gmt":"2022-05-20T21:31:03","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2322738"},"modified":"2022-05-20T17:59:32","modified_gmt":"2022-05-21T00:59:32","slug":"hyundai-to-open-6-5b-ev-factory-in-georgia","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/20\/hyundai-to-open-6-5b-ev-factory-in-georgia\/","title":{"rendered":"Hyundai to open $6.5B EV factory in Georgia"},"content":{"rendered":""speakable-summary\">Hyundai is the latest automaker to announce plans to open an EV factory in Georgia, the same state where Rivian is preparing to break ground on its"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/02\/rivian-lands-1-5b-incentives-package-to-build-massive-ev-factory-in-georgia\/\">controversial plant.<\/a><\/p>\nHyundai\u2019s $6.5 billion EV and battery manufacturing facility outside of Savannah will further the state\u2019s goal of becoming a major regional hub for the EV industry. As sales of electric vehicles start to surge, the Peach State aims to establish a closed-loop battery-electric ecosystem that includes rare-earth mining, battery and chip production, and auto parts manufacturing, according to state officials.<\/p>\nHyundai’s capital investment, which includes"https:\/\/www.georgia.org\/hyundaimotorgroup\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">$1 billion from non-affiliated suppliers<\/a>, represents the largest economic development deal recruited by Georgia, officials said Friday. Hyundai expects to create 8,100 jobs at the 2,293-acre site.<\/p>\nGeorgia has become aggressive in its efforts to attract manufacturers, awarding Rivian the"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/02\/rivian-lands-1-5b-incentives-package-to-build-massive-ev-factory-in-georgia\/\">state\u2019s largest-ever incentives package<\/a> of $1.5 billion to build a plant on 2,000 acres east of Atlanta. In return, Rivian has pledged to hire 7,500 workers at an average annual salary of $56,000 by the end of 2028. However, the project has"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/11\/3-predictions-for-rivians-q1-earnings\/\">stirred up local controversy<\/a>; residents have"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/11\/rivian-shares-pop-even-as-q1-losses-widen-amid-ev-production-ramp-up\/\">rallied around concerns<\/a> ranging from land preservation to the use of tax dollars.<\/p>\nThe issue became political, as opponents of the Rivian plant mobilize against Gov. Brian Kemp ahead of his race for re-election in November.<\/p>\nRivian plans to break ground this summer and open by early 2024.<\/p>\nHyundai\u2019s site represents a collaboration among four Georgia counties that used proceeds from selling property to Amazon to help fund the $61 million land purchase. The partnership, which calls itself the Savannah Harbor-Interstate 16 Corridor Joint Development Authority (JDA), pooled the plots to create a \u201cshovel-ready mega-site\u201d for a large manufacturer.<\/p>"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\nHyundai said the plant will begin production in 2025 with the"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/04\/14\/evs-dominate-2022-world-car-awards\/\">capacity to build<\/a> 300,000 vehicles per year.<\/p>\nOfficials hope to replicate the model to attract more mega-site manufacturing projects to the state.<\/p>\n"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/09\/27\/how-fords-electrification-footprint-will-change-with-planned-investments\/\">SK On<\/a>, a South Korean EV lithium-ion battery maker, is building a $2.6 billion EV battery complex nearby. The company, which said its plant will be able to power 310,000 electric vehicles annually, has contracts with Ford and Volkswagen.<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"Hyundai is the latest automaker to announce plans to open an EV factory in Georgia, the same state where Rivian is preparing to break ground on its controversial plant. Hyundai\u2019s $6.5 billion EV and battery manufacturing facility outside of Savannah will further the state\u2019s goal of becoming a major regional hub for the EV industry. launch startup Skyroot successfully completes full-duration stage test"},"content":{"rendered":""speakable-summary\">"YouTube video player\" src=\"https:\/\/www.youtube.com\/embed\/9LWiX3YC9Lc\" width=\"560\" height=\"315\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen=\"allowfullscreen\"><\/iframe><\/p>\n"https:\/\/skyroot.in\/index\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Skyroot<\/a>, the first private Indian company to design, build and test a solid rocket propulsion stage, has reached another key milestone in the development of its Vikram-I launch vehicle: a full-duration test of the rocket\u2019s third stage.<\/p>\nThe third stage, dubbed Kalam-100 in homage to Indian rocket scientist and former President A.P.J. Abdul Kalam, is just one part of the company\u2019s debut rocket. Vikram-I includes three solid fuel stages, plus a liquid-fueled kick stage that\u2019s designed to serve the small satellite launch market. It\u2019s designed to carry up to 480 kilograms to low-inclination orbits, and the company says on its website that it\u2019s designed to be assembled and launched from any launch site within 24 hours.<\/p>\nVikram-I is one of a trio of rockets Skyroot is currently developing; the other two, Vikram-II and Vikram-III, will be able to carry heavier payloads with multiple orbital insertions, Skyroot says.<\/p>\nThe test-firing of the rocket stage took place at a private test range in Nagpur City, India, CEO Pawan Kumar Chandana told TechCrunch in an email. That range belongs to Skyroot investor and industrial explosives, ammunitions and propulsion systems manufacturer Solar Industries India.<\/p>\nThe next steps will be test firings for Stage 1 and Stage 2, Chandana said. The company\u2019s existing funding, including an $11 million Series A and a $4.5 million bridge round, will cover most of the costs of testing. Skyroot is in the process of raising a Series B to take the company to \u201cmultiple orbital launches,\u201d he said.<\/p>\nAll this funding should get Skyroot to a technology demonstration launch by the end of this year, with the company\u2019s first commercial orbital mission early next year. That launch would take off from India\u2019s spaceport on Sriharikota Island, and would make Skyroot the first private Indian company to build and launch private rockets.<\/p>"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"Skyroot, the first private Indian company to design, build and test a solid rocket propulsion stage, has reached another key milestone in the development of its Vikram-I launch vehicle: a full-duration test of the rocket\u2019s third stage. The third stage, dubbed Kalam-100 in homage to Indian rocket scientist and former President A.P.J. Abdul Kalam, is biomarkers are healthcare\u2019s next frontier"},"content":{"rendered":""article__contributor-byline-wrapper\">\n"article__contributor-byline\">\n\t"contributor-byline__contributor\">\n\t\t"byline__author\">\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t"byline__author-name\">Sunny Kumar<\/span>\n\t\t\t\t\t\t"byline__author-title\" style=\"display: block;\">Contributor<\/span>\n\t\t<\/div>\n\n\t\t\t\t"contributor__twitter\">\n\t\t\t"_blank\" href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/sunnyk_md\">\n\t\t\t\t\t"icon icon--twitter icon--white\" viewBox=\"0 0 20 20\" version=\"1.1\" aria-labelledby=\"title\">\n\t\tShare on Twitter<\/title>\n\t\t"M20,4c-0.7,0.3-1.5,0.6-2.4,0.7c0.9-0.5,1.5-1.4,1.8-2.3c-0.8,0.5-1.7,0.8-2.6,1C16.1,2.5,15,2,13.8,2c-2.3,0-4.1,1.9-4.1,4.2c0,0.3,0,0.7,0.1,1C6.4,7,3.4,5.4,1.4,2.9C1,3.5,0.8,4.1,0.8,4.9c0,1.4,0.7,2.7,1.8,3.5C2,8.4,1.4,8.2,0.8,7.9v0.1c0,2,1.4,3.7,3.3,4.1c-0.4,0.1-0.7,0.2-1.1,0.2c-0.3,0-0.5,0-0.8-0.1c0.5,1.7,2,2.9,3.8,2.9c-1.4,1.1-3.2,2-5.1,2c-0.3,0-0.7,0-1-0.1c1.8,1.2,4,1.7,6.3,1.7c7.5,0,11.7-6.4,11.7-12V6.1C18.8,5.6,19.4,4.8,20,4z\"\/>\t<\/svg>\n\t\t\t\t<\/a>\n\t\t<\/div>\n\t\t\t<\/div>\n\n\t\t"contributor-byline__bio\">\n\t\tSunny Kumar, MD, MBA is a partner at GSR Ventures, an early-stage venture capital firm focused on healthcare technology with more than $3.5 billion under management.\t<\/div>\n\t\n\t<\/div>\n<\/div>"speakable-summary\">"featured__span-first-words\">Blood pressure, body<\/span> temperature, hemoglobin A1c levels and other biomarkers have been used for decades to track disease. While this information is essential for chronic condition management, these and many other physiological measurements are typically captured only periodically, making it difficult to reliably detect early meaningful changes.<\/p>\nMoreover, biomarkers extracted from blood require uncomfortable blood draws, can be expensive to analyze, and again, are not always timely.<\/p>\nHistorically, continuous tracking of an individual\u2019s vital signs meant they had to be in a hospital. But that’s not true anymore. Digital biomarkers, collected from wearable sensors or through a device, offer healthcare providers an abundance of traditional and new data to precisely monitor and even predict a patient\u2019s disease trajectory.<\/p>\nWith cloud-based servers and sophisticated, yet inexpensive, sensors both on the body and off, patients can be monitored at home more effectively than in a hospital, especially when the sensor data is analyzed with artificial intelligence (AI) and machine-learning technology.<\/p>\nOpportunities for digital biomarkers<\/h2>\nA major opportunity for digital biomarkers is in addressing neurodegenerative diseases such as mild cognitive impairment, Alzheimer\u2019s disease and Parkinson\u2019s disease.<\/p>\nNeurodegenerative disease is a major target for digital biomarker development due to a lack of easily accessible indicators that can help providers diagnose and manage these conditions. A definitive diagnosis for Alzheimer\u2019s disease today, for example, generally requires positron emission tomography (PET), magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) or other imaging studies, which are often"https:\/\/www.healthimaging.com\/topics\/practice-management\/jama-us-spends-most-healthcare-and-imaging-reason-why\">expensive<\/a> and"https:\/\/www.choosingwisely.org\/patient-resources\/alzheimers-disease-testing\/\">not always accurate or reliable<\/a>.<\/p>\nCost savings and other benefits<\/h2>\nDigital biomarkers have the potential to unlock significant value for healthcare providers, companies and, most importantly, patients and families, by detecting and slowing the development of these diseases.
"extra-crunch-offer-container\"><\/div>","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"Historically, continuous tracking of an individual\u2019s vital signs meant they had to be in a hospital. But that’s not true sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" \/><\/a><\/p>\n"speakable-summary\">After a brief hiatus, TechCrunch\u2019s Summer Party is back to reconvene with the best of Silicon Valley and celebrate startup excellence. We invite you to join us for an evening of networking and discovery with canap\u00e9s, cocktails and plenty of startup energy.\u00a0 This time honored tradition is now an event staple in the startup world and has a history of being the place to meet your future investor, co-founder, or acquirer.<\/p>\n"speakable-summary\">The fun will take place this June at the offices of Mayfield in the heart of Menlo Park. Join us for a summer evening you won\u2019t forget!<\/p>\nWe are capping the size of this event this year and the number of tickets available will be limited. Tickets will be released in groups with those on our mailing list being notified first. Sign up for our newsletter to be informed when tickets are released but once they\u2019re gone, they\u2019re gone. No sales will be available at the door.<\/p>\nWhat is your cancellation policy?<\/h3>\n"speakable-summary\">All tickets are non-refundable but you can transfer your ticket to another individual via the link in your registration confirmation email.<\/p>\nWhat is your COVID vaccination policy?<\/h3>\nYou must be fully-vaccinated with a booster for entry. Vaccination check will happen before you are allowed to enter the event. Masks are not required but are highly recommended. We will communicate any changes to this policy or specific requirements as we get closer to the event to ensure everyone understands the health requirements for attendance.<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"After a brief hiatus, TechCrunch\u2019s Summer Party is back to reconvene with the best of Silicon Valley and celebrate startup excellence. watershed for the modern data stack. Even as it\u2019s being rapidly adopted by data teams, innovation within it continues to accelerate. From the data warehouse to the data lake to the lakehouse, the rise of analytics engineering, and more, it\u2019s clear that change is still afoot.<\/p>\nThe modern data stack on the lakehouse has proven to dramatically simplify data architecture for enterprises to handle all their data, analytics and AI. It provides the freedom to create powerful data products built on open standards and across multiple clouds.<\/p>\nSo what comes next?<\/p>\nJoin a panel of co-founders and CEOs from Databricks, dbt Labs and Fivetran, the innovators of the modern data stack, as they discuss:<\/p>\n\nEnabling more people and enterprises to benefit from the modern data stack on the lakehouse<\/li>\nThe impact of the modern data stack on the data strategies of the future and how we get there<\/li>\nImplications of this future on how we work with analytics and AI<\/li>\n<\/ul>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"The last few years have been a watershed for the modern data stack. From the data warehouse to the data lake to the lakehouse, the rise of analytics engineering, and more, it\u2019s clear that change is still afoot. Brown is Chief Visionary Officer and founder of Impossible Foods, a company at the forefront of making nutritious, delicious meat and dairy products from plants to satisfy meat lovers and address the environmental impact of animal farming. The idea for Impossible Foods came to Pat while he was on sabbatical from his position as an HHMI investigator and professor of biochemistry at the Stanford University School of Medicine. In reflecting on how he could use his training and experience to make the largest positive impact on the world, he realized there was a way to make delicious, affordable meat and dairy products, directly from plants \u2013 that would be better for the environment and for consumers. In 2011, Pat chose to devote himself full time to Impossible Foods. After receiving his BA, MD and PhD (in Biochemistry) at the University of Chicago, Pat completed a residency in pediatrics at Chicago\u2019s Children\u2019s Memorial Hospital. As a fellow with Mike Bishop and Harold Varmus, he defined the mechanism by which HIV and other retroviruses incorporate their genes into the genomes of the cells they infect. At Stanford, Pat and colleagues developed DNA microarrays \u2013 a new technology that made it possible to monitor the activity of all the genes in a genome \u2013 along with the first methods for analyzing, visualizing and interpreting global gene expression programs. He pioneered the use of gene expression patterns to classify cancers and improve prediction of their clinical course. He has also been a leader in making scientific and medical research results freely available to scientists, physicians and the public. With Harold Varmus, then Director of the National Institutes of Health, and Berkeley professor Michael Eisen, he founded the Public Library of Science, a nonprofit scientific publisher that has transformed the publishing industry by making scientific and medical research results freely available to the public. Pat is a member of the National Academy of Sciences and the Institute of Medicine and recipient of the American Cancer Society Medal of Honor.<\/p>","cbAvatar":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/04\/Pat-Brown-.jpg","company":"Impossible Foods","featured":1,"name":"Patrick Brown","uuid":"3c76fff73c7d29bf7f421db101e2e29b1650302943","cb_tag":0,"position":"Founder & Chief Visionary Officer","links":{"crunchbase":"","twitter":"https:\/\/twitter.com\/ImpossibleFoods?ref_src=twsrcgoogletwcampserptwgrauthor"}},{"bio":"Carol M. Carol served as Assistant to President Barack Obama and Director of the White House Office of Energy and Climate Change Policy, where she oversaw the coordination of environmental, energy, climate, transport, and related policy across the U.S. federal government. During her tenure, the White House secured the largest investment ever in clean energy and established the cleaner cars standards that included both new automobile fuel efficiency standards and first ever greenhouse gas reduction standards. Carol is the longest serving Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency. As Administrator, she adopted the most stringent air pollution standards in U.S. history; set the first fine particle clean air standard; and spearheaded the reauthorization of the Safe Drinking Water Act as well as the Food Quality Protection Act. Carol was known for working with both environmentalists and industry to find solutions and focusing on protecting vulnerable populations and promote environmental equity. Carol is Senior of Counsel at Covington where she provides counsel to industry leaders in the energy, transportation, and consumer product sectors on regulatory matters, environmental impact issues, corporate sustainability, and strategic partnership development to advance clean energy, ESG, and other business priorities. In addition to projects developed for his clients, other notable developments include the iBOT\u2122 mobility device and the Segway\u00ae Human Transporter.
